name: Moco Museum Amsterdam
description: Dedicated to modern art, contemporary art, and street art, this independent museum in Amsterdam's Museumplein is a favorite amongst the youth.
address: Honthorststraat 20 Next To Van Gogh Museum, 1071 DE Amsterdam The Netherlands

top_reviews.title: Unexpectedly one of the best art museums in Amsterdam!
top_reviews.review: The museum was full of surprises. We loved all the exhibition rooms, which are all different. Kids loved learning about Banksy, KAWS, Hirst, Kusama - list goes on and on. The interactive outdoor garden was great too. 3D component through the app is a delight. I recommend visiting Moco 100% when in Amsterdam!

top_reviews.title: Great exhibition
top_reviews.review: Exhibition was great. Loved all the modern art and installations that we saw but unfortunately it was so unpleasantly hot in the house with the unseasonably hot weather and no effective cooling system, that we didn’t spend as much time as we would have liked there. Thought provoking art there certainly.

top_reviews.title: Amazing! A Must-Visit!!
top_reviews.review: The best modern Art and most thought provoking! The contrast of hosting location being in the very traditional building and the hosted art being the most forefront of our society today, highlight the long lasting effect Art has on us. In Art We Trust! We need more Moco in the world!

top_reviews.title: small museum but worth a visit
top_reviews.review: Small but great exposition of some wonderfull art. Great collection. In the basement some great surprises. Especially the lights in the last room on the right caught my attention. Giftshop is a bit expensive though.

top_reviews.title: Cheerful museum in Amsterdam
top_reviews.review: I love it. Made me smile see all artworks especially Banksy. Highly recommended. May need to book in advance. It was queue when I got in and the Dutch building is a big house but it’s gorgeous.

top_reviews.title: Vibrant and colourful exhibits
top_reviews.review: Did not plan to visit but came out of Rijksmuseum and saw there was no queue as walked past & it was included on our I Amsterdam card. Worth the stop, interesting, colourful and totally more so than I’d expected. If you have the city card then worth stopping off at.

top_reviews.title: Rare, Like Rocking Horse Sh#te
top_reviews.review: Art is in the eye of the beholder, from the reviews I get it that some may not like it, but we’ve visited a lot of galleries- seen the headline acts and this wee museum did not disappoint. Yes some exhibits I don’t understand, NFT’s, but others I can certainly appreciate, I try to keep an open mind on art and try - as Public Enemy say “Don’t Believe The Hype”. I can appreciate the artist’s message, their thought and the presentation within this gallery. There were some highlights, I was pleased to see, and found the descriptions provided by the gallery entirely adequate. My “Higher Art” (one for the Scots readers’) teachers would be proud, I’m sure. If you’re looking for still life paintings, or fine portraiture this ain’t for you, but there were plenty happy faces around, plenty people taking their time to take in the art to say good on you Moco… AND, oh and there’s a huge rocking horse to climb up on and get a photo taken!

top_reviews.title: Great, intimate museum
top_reviews.review: I really enjoyed this museum. It was easier to reserve a ticket here, compared to other museums in Amsterdam, but that’s not the only reason to visit it. When I was there, I saw a wonderful Banksy exhibit, and many other great artworks. I also appreciated the digital art exhibit as well as the outdoor sculptures. Highly recommended!

top_reviews.title: Modern art gem
top_reviews.review: A fantastic museum, well worth a visit. Full of contemporary artwork, beautifully collated and displayed. The building itself is lovely and leads you through the different works of art seamlessly. I haven’t been anywhere like it, it was all very intimate in its display. Staff were friendly and helpful too.

top_reviews.title: Enjoyable Modern Art Museum
top_reviews.review: This is an excellent modern art museum with a varied collection. It’s housed in a an older building, which creates a fun and interesting contrast to the modern art (the building was unexpected, as in our experience most modern art museums are modern buildings, themselves). Would highly recommend. It’s a smaller museum, so don’t expect to be spending multiple hours here. But even so, it exceeded our expectations and made for an enjoyable visit.

name: Madame Tussauds Amsterdam
description: Pose beside the wax figures of a bevy of international stars, world leaders, and Dutch household names like King Willem-Alexander and Johan Cruyff.

top_reviews.title: Pictures bad quality!
top_reviews.review: Nice wax statues but the pictures they made from our family are totally unacceptable!!! All pictures are too dark, not sharp and some people are cut and are shown half. POOR QUALITY AT ALL! So €20,- in the garbage!! Advice: Renew your apparatus and train your staff.

top_reviews.title: Amazing experience. The best place to make nice pictures
top_reviews.review: Amazing experience! Very friendly attitude from the whole team from the beginning till the end of visit. I visited it by myself , but still was a lot of fun. I was planning to visit it just for 1 hour, but as it has a lot to do , it took me more time . So put nice clothes, don’t bring heavy stuff with with you, because there is no locker or wardrobe , and enjoy it . And one more advise , don’t put green color clothes, if you want to make a lot of pictures on special rooms , like the famous stands with Amsterdam signs , Van Gogh portrait . Because you will get a shadow on the photo. But at least for video with charly Chaplin works everything, as it black and white. You can have some nice coffee or beer in karaoke bar inside. Special thanks for Cheyen. Don’t loose this museum if you are in Amsterdam ;)

top_reviews.title: Visiting Madame Tussauds in a wheelchair
top_reviews.review: I was most impressed by the kindness of all the staff there, particularly Rob, thanks to whom Christopher, who is in a wheelchair, was able to use the staff lifts to get to the various floors. We had a most enjoyable visit indeed. So glad we got photographs taken - a lovely souvenir to take back to France with us on 14th December. Thank you all for such a lovely experience.

top_reviews.title: Fantastic fun.
top_reviews.review: A visit to Madame Tussauds is a very fun time spent in great company. You get to have fun, laugh and take lots of cool photos with famous people and more. If you take 2 hours and visit this magical place, you definitely won't regret it. Definitely recommended.

top_reviews.title: Great experience!
top_reviews.review: I very much enjoyed visiting Madame Tussauds last week! I especially liked the interactive parts (photos and videos) organized by the museum. I would recommend this visit to outgoing people who like celebrities

top_reviews.title: Disappointment
top_reviews.review: The museum experience was good, but I think the museum is not the same to be exaggerated. There is a high fee to buy digital copies of the photographs at the exit of the museum. The museum fee is appropriate, but paying such a high fee at the exit of the museum spoils the whole ambiance. Also, although some videos were taken inside the museum, only photos were shared for a fee. Unfortunately, considering the whole experience and our expenses, I can say it was a bad experience.

top_reviews.title: Definitely check Madame Tussauds Out. We were glad we did.
top_reviews.review: Had a lot of fun during the tour. If you have been to a Madame Tussauds, remember they are all different regarding who is featured in the museum. Worth visiting and letting loose with the fun things you can be a part of in the museum. You'll see what I mean. Go & Have A Fun Filled Time.

top_reviews.title: Great Place. Had a good couple of hours with the family.
top_reviews.review: Very well planned, lovely layout and great staff as usual. If it is your first visit, then definitely a must see at Amsterdam.. If you've seen the others in London or the US, this exhibit is definitely smaller.. so just be prepared with your expectations.

top_reviews.title: Always A Good Time
top_reviews.review: It’s my mission to visit every Madame Tussaud’s on the planet and this was a very good one! Some figure are old and slightly out of date and some are brand new and excellently crafted. It’s always interesting to see which ‘areas’ each museum has and this one was excellent. Lots of immersive activities as well scattered around which you don’t always see. Very reasonably priced I thought at about €25 each. We went late afternoon on a weekday and it wasn’t busy at all. Would recommend.

top_reviews.title: Having fun interacting with the wax figures at Madame Tussauds
top_reviews.review: We had never been to a Madame Tussauds before, but were pleasantly surprised. My Mum was reluctant to go in thinking there were probably better things to do in Amsterdam, but she was soon into it interacting with the wax models. Definitely fun and a great thing to do. Pretty life like figures and some fun ones to interact with.

name: Amsterdam Museum
description: Over the next few years, our main location at the Burgerweeshuis on the Kalverstraat will be undergoing renovation. In the meantime, we can be found at Amstel 51, online, and at other locations in Amsterdam.

name: Centraal Station
description: Completed in 1889 and located in the heart of town, this neo-Renaissance rail station was designed by P.J.H. Cuypers, the same person who designed the famous Rijksmuseum.
category: Points of Interest & Landmarks Architectural Buildings Public Transportation Systems

top_reviews.title: Convenient location in the city center
top_reviews.review: Our acquaintance with the city began from here. The building has its own long history. In the very center, quite convenient transport interchange. The Centraal Station building is one of the architectural landmarks of the city. It was built in 1889 by the architect Peter Kuipers. By the way, he designed the Rijksmuseum building. Both buildings are very similar to each other, but are located at opposite ends of the historical center of Amsterdam.

top_reviews.title: Main transportation hub
top_reviews.review: Centraal Station is busy, noisy, hustling and bustling with energy but surprisingly efficient. The signage to the trains and metro lines are very easy to flow, the ticket checkpoints work like a charm (charge directly to your credit card, use ApplePay, or IAmsterdam card). There are long walks from one metro line to another on occasion, but noting to worry about. The station is very clean and has plenty of places to grab a snack.

top_reviews.title: A Modern Transport Hub in an Attractive Old Shell
top_reviews.review: Lovely iconic building in central Amsterdam. A good point for bus and train connections. Nice to view across the water. There's plenty of shops, eateries and luggage storage and plenty of information boards. A modern hub in an old shell.

top_reviews.title: Similar to another creation by Pierre Cuypers- the Rijksmuseum
top_reviews.review: On this visit, like the previous one, I went straight from the train station to the Rijksmuseum and experienced deja vu. These buildings are so similar. This is not surprising, because they were built by one architect Pierre Cuypers, and in parallel. The municipality chose the places for construction from two options. The second was Leidenplein. The current building, built in 1889, separated the city from the harbor, which many did not like, because it contradicted the history and spirit of Amsterdam. Now, instead of ships from the Dutch West Indies, America and Japan, trains arrived here. At the same time, the station itself was built on an artificial island of 8,700 piles, which is not surprising for the Netherlands. There are 6 platforms at the station from which 150 thousand passengers leave and arrive daily (in 2019 there were 213 thousand). At the same time, Amsterdam station is only the second in the country in terms of traffic, second only to Utrecht. Needless to say, the station is very convenient inside: cafes, shops, escalators. Everything is like at all major railway stations in the country. ..

top_reviews.title: fantastic station! 🚂
top_reviews.review: Really pretty railway station, steeped in history. Great for the history nerd, train spotter or anyone who is fascinated in architecture. Has an array of shops, toilets, and the concourse is busy but always moving due to the open space

top_reviews.title: Good to visit at both day and night time
top_reviews.review: It's good to visit with friends. It's looks beautiful in the night as the lights reflect off the water. The air is also fresh and refreshing alongside the river. You can visit with friends at night and have drinks along side the shore.

top_reviews.title: A vibrant city
top_reviews.review: We got there pretty late in the afternoon. It was dark already when we took a train from airport hotel to downtown. We can feel the Christmas atmosphere. Tourist boat in the canal is running. A public event was ongoing near the Centraal on Palestine human right. It is such a vibrant city.

top_reviews.title: Very Impressive Building
top_reviews.review: A very impressive station building dominating the area at the end of the Damrak. It’s close to the cruise terminal, with transport links via trams, canal boats, ferry boats, and Eurostar trains too. It was extremely busy and once outside, the cyclists rules do take care as their speeds are impressive if not dangerous!

top_reviews.title: Essential to this Country
top_reviews.review: We passed through this big busy train station many times. The Netherlands is famous for excellent public transport, so there are trains everywhere. In Amsterdam they arrive at this big station, which can be very crowded and chaotic. Many of the city trams come here. It is not pretty, but it functions well and is essential.

top_reviews.title: Central Station Amsterdam
top_reviews.review: A visit to Central Station in Amsterdam is an automatic for those traveling to or from the airport by train. We found the train station lovely as well as easy to use the tap to pay method to get to where we wanted to go by train. Amsterdam is very walkable, so once out of the train station, it only takes a few minutes to get out of the hustle and bustle of the city before you're wandering through the quiet canals.

name: Molen Van Sloten
description: The Sloten Windmill is a functioning draining mill and at the same time the only windmill in Amsterdam which is open daily to the public. The Mill is situated in the outskirts of Amsterdam not far from Schiphol Airport. It controls the water level in the western part of Amsterdam. This area is situated more than 2 meters below sea level. The Sloten Windmill is a rebuilt mill, dating from 1847. The whole year long the Mill can be visited daily (except Jan. 1st, April 27th and December 25 and 26). The windmill is a non-profit organisation, run by volunteers. Knowledgeable guides will gladly explain the working of the mill during a guided tour. And if possible the miller will demonstrate how the top of the mill is turned, or how to stop the mill.

top_reviews.title: Great people and very interesting
top_reviews.review: We had a great time at this cute mill. The two ladies there were especially nice and even gave us a private tour in German, without us having to ask for it. I loved learning about mills in general and this one in peticular. It is a great activity if you need to escape the loud and busy city for a few hours.

top_reviews.title: Fascinating insight into the area and how the 17th century engineering is still relevant today.
top_reviews.review: Many thanks to Olaf and the team for their hospitality. This is a little off the beaten track but well worth the trip if you want to understand how the Netherlands works in terms of water management. Olaf was a great guide, very knowledgeable and engaging.

top_reviews.title: Excellent tour
top_reviews.review: The tour guide, a young man (can’t recall his name) was knowledgeable, friendly, and a delight to spend time with. His stories were quite interesting. He made us feel very welcome! I highly recommend this fascinating tour

top_reviews.title: A lovely and informative tour
top_reviews.review: Decided to check out a working windmill on a rainy day in Amsterdam. Was amazed by all that i learnt in the hour and so cool getting to see the inside workings. Fred was a great tour guide and very enthusiastic about what he does. Would certainly recommend!

top_reviews.title: Amsterdam in a nutshell
top_reviews.review: The best windmill tour I have ever attended. So much history and an inclusive experience of artefacts, mechanical engineering and artistry. The tour explained in details hows the windmill operated since 1847 and how it is still of use in these present times. The souvenir shop is amazing and the prices are the cheapest you could find in the whole of Amsterdam. Definitely a very highly recommended experience.

top_reviews.title: Absolutely worth a visit
top_reviews.review: Having lived in the area for a year, finally visited and wish had gone before. The Guide was truly illuminating, thank you! Tour encompasses the history of NL, and 'the 'Dam', water levels, polders etc. The windmill itself is a rare fully functioning working model, used in the the area to control the water levels. Together with working models of their evolution in NL, you get to see the whole structure, with original parts, sails under way etc. Engineers will love! With insights into how NL built itself into one of the most powerful European countries, the 'mills played a major part - and learn the secret "sails" language too. Get out of Amsterdam for a day and away from tourists! There's a cheese house and brewery adjacent to the Molen, a new fish restaurant nearby, and quaint Sloten village itself (older than Amsterdam), plus decent local restaurants too for lunch/dinner ('Later on the Water'/Kirksizcht - (the former with canal side tables) - and an amazing (tiny) ice cream house (IJshoeve Sloten) which makes wonderful grapefruit sorbet.

top_reviews.title: Such Charisma and Grace
top_reviews.review: Absolutely fantastic. From London, lovely landlmark. I was with my buddy, we loved the tour, the man spoke so eloquently. 10/10 would RECOMMEND. P.s my friend w/o the glasses, made me go all the way to Amsterdam to see Molen Van Sloten

top_reviews.title: Must-see windmill experience!
top_reviews.review: In English, because we don’t speak Dutch, unfortunately! We stumbled on the windmill while exploring the area and wanted to find out more, so booked a tour. We were greeted by the tour guide who was very enthusiastic and knowledgable, making us excited for the experience. The tour itself was very insightful, giving us a comprehensive understanding of the history and importance of windmills to The Netherlands. We were shown maps, models, parts of the windmill and inside (which was pretty awesome!). We saw how the windmill operates and and how it relates to the surrounding landscape. From the top, there was a stunning birds eye view of the town. The tour was a very fair price, the guide was fantastic and extremely well-educated on the topic. She answered all our questions, and even made us a coffee! We’re so glad we stumbled on this fantastic windmill and would recommend to anyone in the area. Thank you so much for the experience! From England and Egypt 🏴󠁧󠁢󠁥󠁮󠁧󠁿🇪🇬

top_reviews.title: Great experience
top_reviews.review: The tour was great and the guide amazing. He was one of the best storytellers I met. Emphasizing his words the windmill showed a lot of fascinating sides. We even could climb on one part of the mill.

top_reviews.title: Excellent
top_reviews.review: Very interesting and informative tour. Kept adults and children engaged. The tour guide was friendly and professional. Highly reccomended!! Thank you to the team. Great value for money and the Rembrandt audio visual story was an added bonus that we weren’t expecting. Thank you !!

name: Red Light District
description: Amsterdam’s De Wallen area is home to one of the world’s most famous red light districts. Take a stroll to soak up the rousing yet beautiful lights, or visit the Red Lights Secrets Museum to learn more about Amsterdam’s sex work profession. The district is also known for its trendy coffee shops, bars, and clubs. The best time to see the district is in the early evening or at night, when the lights begin to illuminate the narrow streets. The area is safe, but it can get very busy, and taking photos or videos of workers is illegal. – Tripadvisor

top_reviews.title: Super interesting perspective of the red light area
top_reviews.review: Pablo Pascal was the best tour guide. This tour is set in a context of an historic introduction into Amsterdam central areas including an informed view of the red light district. Pablo was so informed and so interesting to listen to. I hope you are lucky enough to get him.

top_reviews.title: Adult tourism activities with friends
top_reviews.review: I stayed there for say about a week, it was a fun travel for recreation and sightseeing and much with friends. It is a open display of world about alternate fun in a healthy way. Alot of shops about sex toy, alcohol, marijuana and other smoke, paid fun ladies, crowd with similar vibe. I made few new friends who shared about their personal intimate experience at Delhi India with Omyale Pippa an Companion (nice and friendly crowd from all over the world), Kind of average experience.

top_reviews.title: Sexy Girls and excellent service
top_reviews.review: Better than other places many exotic provider from various countries (may be i was lucky enough), met one asian girl (shared contact of Ojasvi Love from Delhi, Indie) from and another european both were talented and beautiful. Cindrella from Latvia was another good contact, Blisha from Holland is too welcoming. I must go place to try your luck about flings! I really liked the service, crowd, toy shopping and food. Solo traveller never feel like solo here, so many things to keep you busy. A must try for seekers looking for Adult open-ness.

top_reviews.title: Awesome Holland!!
top_reviews.review: What a fabulous city Amsterdam is.. history..Modern-day..easy to move around ( watch out for the Bikes though..so much to see and do. A wonderful place if you want to bade and visit some of the other countries..Paris.. 4 hrs away..Brussels 3 ish hrs away..easily accessible. The Trains were comfortable/clean. I felt safe walking the city.. cant wait to get back and explore more of the city and countryside..

top_reviews.title: Sexy Beautiful Red Lights
top_reviews.review: We visited Amsterdam with an open mind, unsure what to expect. Well. It was great. The city is beautiful with its canals, buildings and bars. The red light disitrict is in the heart of the city, easy to get to and 15-20 min walk from Central station. We had a giggle in the sex shops but our first place was the Sex museum opposite the Central Station. It was brilliant with diaplays and history through the years with some eye ( watering ) openers too. We had a good laugh in there. Not as much window shopping as we had expected, dont laugh or point at the girls, its frowned upon. We went in the sex palace several times for the peep show at 2 euros a go. Think my wife enjoyed it more than i did. Lokking at minge as she called it. Again, a laugh and a giggle, tongue in cheek. Some of the girls ( ladies ) were entertaining, smiling, some of the older ones didnt look to happy to be there. Expect to pay between 6 and 10 euro for a beer. 10 to 15 for gins/mixers, irish coffee etc. Paid 8 euro for a spliff and 9 euro for a space cake. No more than felt a bit floaty, happy. Giggly. Stay away from the street sellers. They're easy to spot a mile off.

top_reviews.title: Still has a real buzz to it.
top_reviews.review: As people watching is one of our favourite pass times this was right up our alley so to speak. Went there both during the day and night, noting it stretches beyond the one street during the day there were lots of families strolling around and had a family atmosphere about it. Night time bit busier windows full. There are lots of places to eat and drink in and around it and we found prices reasonable. Recommended for nearly all ages especially if you have not seen or experienced any thing like this before. Was there 40 years ago and doesn't seemed to have changed much

top_reviews.title: Worth a look.
top_reviews.review: We walked the Red light district and to be honest it’s quite a dirty area. A lot of rubbish on the side of the canal. The smell of weed was nice mind. I don’t use it but it’s a nice smell. Busy area and plenty of things to see 🫣

top_reviews.title: Now that was different…
top_reviews.review: Had heard all about this part of town but you’ve just got to experience it to believe it.. Not as dirty and gross as you’d probably imagine it to be. Very interesting and it got old quite quick. The women in the windows were quite amusing and would get very angry with you fast if you weren’t a customer. Glad we made the stroll and can now say that we’ve been there.

top_reviews.title: It’s what Amsterdam is about right?
top_reviews.review: A must visit when you come to Amsterdam, it is all part of the culture! The canals are beautiful and the actual area itself is nice. This is where you will see the various small “windows” where the ladies are within. It does have that strange feeling, however the general atmosphere was good. Definitely worth a visit.

top_reviews.title: Worth a visit
top_reviews.review: You cannot go to the dam and not visit the red light district But be very warned be aware of your belongings and people around you ! Look out for small groups of males hanging around on corners If you get approached do not engage at all …. IGNORE IGNORE IGNORE Also the working girls don’t like being waved at as I found out Have a look but be discreet Casa Rosa sex show was funny and defo worth a visit inside 😂

name: A'dam Lookout
description: LOOKOUT 360º Amsterdam + sensational swing An iconic viewing point in The Netherlands - A’DAM LOOKOUT, has joined the Eiffel Tower, the Fernsehturm and the London Eye. For the daredevils among us, LOOKOUT also has a further adrenalin kick in store. On the roof is Europe’s highest swing. You swing over the edge of the tower at a thrilling height of almost 100 metres above the ground. Highlights: - The most spectacular view of Amsterdam and the surrounding area - A Bird’s-eye view of Amsterdam from the highest swing in Europe - Access to the indoor interactive state-of-the-art Amsterdam exhibition - Free digital photo of your visit to LOOKOUT - Enjoy coffee, breakfast, lunch, dinner and/or cocktails in Madam Restaurant & Sky Bar - Free WIFI available Payments with cards only.

top_reviews.title: A Swinging Time!
top_reviews.review: Just a short ferry ride from Centraal Station, we had a beautiful, sunny day for our trip to the lookout. The experience begins with a Techno-enhanced lift ride to the top, complete with a thrilling light show. Once on top, there are two lookout platforms to help take photos above the screen fence. For the more adventurous, there is "Over The Edge", Europe's highest swing. I will tell you that I am not a fan of roller coasters, or heights, or swinging over the edge of a building, but I wanted to experience it for myself. It is as thrilling and scary as you think it is. I chose to keep my eyes shut for most of it, but feel free to look around (and straight down). It only runs a minute, which was just long enough for me! Afterwards, we enjoyed a drink and soaked in the views. Highly recommended!

top_reviews.title: Amazing attraction
top_reviews.review: We visited the A’dam lookout and throughly enjoyed ourself. The panoramic view all over the city is incredible. We enjoyed the added VR experience and the swing. The staff were very nice and helpful. We will definitely be visiting again in the future

top_reviews.title: Amazing afternoon with amazing views
top_reviews.review: Me and my friend visit whilst on holiday in Amsterdam. We didn’t know about A’DAM LOOKOUT until we got off the train at Amsterdam Centraal. My friend booked the tickets online, which included The Swing, The VR rollercoaster and 2 drinks. Staff we’re all very friendly and helpful. The ride up to the 20th floor in the elevator was unique and fun. The swing was just amazing, such great views. The VR rollercoaster was fun and we enjoyed our drinks (and some Bitterballen) in the bar with some fantastic views across Amsterdam. The audio tour on the Skydeck was very good and gave lots of interesting facts. We will definitely be returning next time we are in Amsterdam.

top_reviews.title: Good date idea or a night out with friends.
top_reviews.review: The view was amazing! There are 2 levels with bars, one indoor, one outdoor, and on each you can walk around and see the city from all directions. My only real complaint, and it's a personal opinion, is that the music wasn't too enjoyable. Was upbeat, but I didn't really recognize any of it. Otherwise, very cool vibe with a mostly young crowd.

top_reviews.title: Amazing! Made Amsterdam for us
top_reviews.review: Amazing! Really made our holiday! We didn’t know anything about this place, it’s sad that even the hotel don’t advertise here. The staff are all fantastic! I’m disabled and everyone above and beyond to make sure I didn’t miss anything and was treated the same as everyone else which is hard to find in Dam as there is so many stairs in attractions. I didn’t go on the swings but if you can I would highly recommend it but if you can’t still come here. The views are amazing, the bar is lovely, really busy but I can see why.

top_reviews.title: Stunning views
top_reviews.review: Really cool place to visit. Me and my other half didn’t go for the swing but the views were stunning and you can even get a picture of yourself on a horse on the roof!!!!!!!!! Easy to get to from Amsterdam train station you just get a ferry from behind the station which is free and constantly running so you aren’t waiting around. Definitely recommended for anybody to see you will get some great views and pictures !

top_reviews.title: Very fun experience overlooking beautiful Amsterdam!
top_reviews.review: Visited this fun attraction while staying in the Adam building during our trip to Amsterdam. The view is perfect, and fairly reasonably priced at around €22 for the view and experience. You also get some free photos and a video to download at the end of the experience. Definitely recommend if you want to see Amsterdam in a different and unique way!

top_reviews.title: Food, views, swings & VR!
top_reviews.review: Perfect way to spend a couple of hours. We booked the lunch experience at Moon, plus the swings and VR. Food was delicious, and really enjoyed the experience of the rotating rstaurant and changing view. Swings were better again, and got some great photos and video after. Finally, the VR!! Make sure your headset is on securely, but other than that it's awesome! So silly but lots of fun. Easy to get to from behind the main station, the ferry is free and runs constantly (at least during the day). 100% worth the visit

top_reviews.title: Great experience!!
top_reviews.review: Worth the visit, as we don't really like the busy life in Amsterdam, we enjoyed the view, the kids got on the Swing and the VR rollercoaster. The Restaurant and bar at the rooftop had excellent service! Highly recommended!!!

top_reviews.title: Gaint Swing and VR Ride.
top_reviews.review: Adam Lookout's Sky Deck offers an absolutely worth-it experience with unparalleled views. The Giant Swing adds an awesome thrill, while the Moon Restaurant enhances the charm with a 360-degree view. Breath-taking scenes unfold, making every moment memorable. Dining high above Amsterdam creates an unforgettable, panoramic perspective of the city's beauty.

name: Our Lord in the Attic Museum Ons' Lieve Heer op Solder
description: Hidden in the heart of the city centre of Amsterdam is a small wonder: Our Lord in the Attic Museum. Visitors will be going on a journey in a unique well-preserved canal house from the 17th century. Narrow corridors and stairs lead to historically decorated living quarters, kitchens and bedsteads, ending in what is literally the highlight of the museum: a complete church in the attic.
breadcrumbs: Our Lord in the Attic Museum Ons' Lieve Heer op Solder
address: Oudezijds Voorburgwal 38-40, 1012 GD Amsterdam The Netherlands

top_reviews.title: Exceeded our expectations, must do!
top_reviews.review: I was hesitating whether to visit or not, and didn't know what to expect. So glad that we did. The visit takes roughly an hour, and there's a lot to take in from history, culture and religion. The place is very well preserved, and definitely worth the time!

top_reviews.title: Lovely atmospheric museum/house
top_reviews.review: A very well set out canal house museum. It is lit in such a way as to recreate how the house would’ve been in the living areas, basically not light at all. The church in the attic is quite staggering in terms the effort gone to in creating it. Some excellent views across the city from the higher windows. Do use the audio guide and take the time to sit and go through the short 3 min introduction as well as looking at the model of the house. Well worth the visit.

top_reviews.title: Enchanting well preserved “hidden” church
top_reviews.review: Historic Catholic Church built 250 years ago on top of three homes on the canal. The exhibits are superb and the church itself is mesmerizing. An audio tour takes you through the history and background. I found this fascinating…. Takes st least one hour with many narrow and difficult staircases

top_reviews.title: Hidden Gem! Not to miss! Learn secular traditions of families who lived here, and the sanctuary hidden upstairs.
top_reviews.review: This museum is a hidden gem. It is a home that is hundreds of years old, which hid a secret Catholic chapel in it’s attic. You will receive a small recorder in your language which corresponds to displays in every room. Point and listen. The history of traditions and customs is fascinating. There are artifacts from secular living of families who lived there, as well as sacred spaces. Please know that there are lots of little rooms to investigate, and some stairs are more like ladders, but original to the home. Free lockers and a coat room are also provided.

top_reviews.title: Interesting!
top_reviews.review: Extremely interesting! It is definitely worth the visit!!! Not only do you see the church in the attic, but you visit various rooms in the home that display the way of life at that time. Highly recommend. It is something quite different.

top_reviews.title: A fabulous museum for our family
top_reviews.review: My kids didn't want to go to museums on our vacation, but even this one they enjoyed. It's very cool to go inside an Amsterdam home. The handheld audio tour is excellent with just enough information of interest, but not so much that kids get bored. The chapel is beautiful. Definitely one of the best stops on our trip. There are free lockers for your personal items. You have to be able to go up and down steep steps.

top_reviews.title: Surprisingly interesting church within a house.
top_reviews.review: Surprisingly, interesting museum that illustrates the early history in the 1600s when Catholic churches were banned by William the Orange of the Netherlands, forcing Catholic worshipers to create churches within their homes. This preserved home and church gives an intimate view of worship life at that time. A comprehensive audio tour helps to understand the shrine. A word of caution. Steep spiral stairs will limit some who have difficulty with climbing stairs.

top_reviews.title: HIdden jewel house in Amsterdam
top_reviews.review: Before visiting Museum Ons’Lieve Heer op Solden I had visited another channel house in Amsterdam, so I had an idea of what I could see. Anyway, what I experimented was beyond my expectations. The aacuracy on the 16th - 17th centuries furniture and ambiances, the architecture solutions to merge 3 houses and build a church for a 100 parishioners, keeping the funcionallity of the houses. It is not the first priority of an Amsterdam’s visitor, but after my expreience I think it is worth spending 90’ of your visit to this gorgeous city in this cute museum.

top_reviews.title: Worth a visit
top_reviews.review: This museum was an excellent find recommended by a friend. A really interesting and very well preserved and presented museum. Navigating around the Museum was easy and the recorded guide easy to use and very informative. We only interacted with staff at the reception desk but they were friendly, efficient and helpful. It took about 60-90mins for our group to complete a tour of the museum.

top_reviews.title: 400 years of Amsterdam history in a one hour tour
top_reviews.review: I very much enjoyed touring the house on the way up the church. The church itself is lovely and very interesting. The audioguide was very good and provided an interesting view of Amsterdam city life over several centuries. Definitely worth the price of admission!

name: Albert Cuyp Market
description: The city's largest street market is just south of the city center.

top_reviews.title: Well worth a visit.
top_reviews.review: Visited this market a couple of times whilst we were in Amsterdam. Great to walk through end to end with lots to see. Great variety of stalls with all sorts to eat. Lovely fresh fish stalls that cook it to order as well.

top_reviews.title: Big, fun outdoor market in Amsterdan
top_reviews.review: Big, fun outdoor market. Check-out the Shwarma stalls and also go visit the stall selling brownies (excellent). Ex-pat American making his own dark chocolate brownies, really good!

top_reviews.title: We visited for Rudi's Stroopwafels!
top_reviews.review: I am grateful that everything in the sprawling downtown area of Amsterdam is within walking distance, including the Albert Cuyp Outdoor Market. We wanted to try the best Stroopwafels in Amsterdam (Rudi's), and we were not disappointed! We also enjoyed wandering through the length of the market, appreciating the other vendors and their varied offerings.

top_reviews.title: Loads of variety
top_reviews.review: We visited on a cold wet Tuesday in January - so probably not representative of how the place really is. However, the market was fully operational and impressive with the variety of items for sale. The locals obviously purchase food and edibles there, and then there are stalls aimed at tourists. The food options were very varied, ranging from fruit and veg to fresh fish, artisan cheeses and even a stall specialising in game birds and meat. There were lots of hot food options also, obviously including the Dutch fries, which you just have to try! Along the outside of the market are some wonderful individual shops which would have occupied us far more if the weather had been kinder. Would definitely return

top_reviews.title: Worth the visit
top_reviews.review: Heard about this market from virtually every guide to Amsterdam I looked at. Strangely smaller than expected. We visited after a morning at a nearby museum and thought we’d try out the street food for lunch. Not every stall or space was occupied, but we found enough to keep us happy. The grilled cheese sandwich place was really good as were the fries from the chap at the very end of the market. We couldn’t miss Rudi’s Stroop wafels and bought lots as gifts too. For us, the best and cheapest you’ll find. For the rest of the market, there are a few cheap souvenir shops which were good for bits and pieces and definitely the best prices for clog slippers (the airports prices were almost double). The cheese stalls were very well priced too and seemed more genuine to the more glossy branded cheese shops on the Damrak and in central Amsterdam. There are of course other stalls selling various other goods ranging from from toiletries to cheap clothes and household items. Overall a very nice experience which served its purpose. Definitely recommend.

top_reviews.title: Amsterdam's hidden gem
top_reviews.review: Good market off the usual tourist routes with a selection of everything whether you're a local looking for fresh food or a stray tourist looking for an original souvenir. If you want an honest bite to eat in a proper Dutch cafe then try 'Cafe Koffiehuis "De Cuyp." (See picture)' It's definitely a locals place but the owner was really friendly and welcomes everyone. The food isn't flash nor expensive but, trust me, it's good. The apple pancake especially.

top_reviews.title: Street market
top_reviews.review: A plethora of stalls serving food, souvenirs, clothes, bags and nicknacks. We only purchased edibles starting with a workman favourite - the mackerel roll. Wandered along a bit and stopped for a homemade stroopwaffle. Since the weather was a bit cold & wet we then finished with a cone of frites (& mayo) to warm us up.

top_reviews.title: Outdoor market with selection of goods
top_reviews.review: A mixture a stalls at this open air market. Easy to access via tram or metro. From souvenirs, jewellery, fabric, food, produce, clothing and much more this market has something for everyone. The area has lots of cafes and restaurants but there is a good selection of “local” food in the market itself. Not an essential must see in Amsterdam but it is worth a visit if you have time.

top_reviews.title: Great Street Market
top_reviews.review: We had excellent pita and sticky stroopwaffelen here. Also bought a few souvenirs and the prices were a lot better than the gift shops in the town. Definitely worth a visit and easy to get to as it has it's own stop on the tram line number 4.

top_reviews.title: Rude Baker
top_reviews.review: we heard about this venue and decided to check it out. There was a stall which has a variety of breads. The man at the stall wasn't very pleasant, in fact, i'm of the opinion that he is rude and not courteous to Asian tourists. It ruined our day. Will hesitate to visit again.

name: Begijnhof
description: Tucked away just off Spui, this delightful collection of houses arranged around an open court is well worth searching out.

top_reviews.title: Worth the time
top_reviews.review: Pretty cool. Quick visit, but a little piece of Amsterdam history. Nice get away from the city noise and hustle n bustle. Good place to rest and take a break from city activity

top_reviews.title: A treasure, not to be missed !
top_reviews.review: This is an amazing place to visit, dot in the middle of old Amsterdam. Begijnhofje houses homes and churches for elderly ladies in the 16/17th century; and still today. You'll find the oldest house in Amsterdam, the absolutely stunningly beautiful catholic hidden church and the English church. You need to be quiet, but you can walk around easily, although some parts are closed for the public. Highly recommended !

top_reviews.title: A complete 100% must visit
top_reviews.review: Been to Amsterdam a few times and cant believe we've never been here. What a calm and serene delight and its free too. Absolutely no idea why people would complain about times as people live here so just go during normal day hours. Lovely old chapels and oldest wooden house in Amsterdam. A 100% must visit

top_reviews.title: A must see. Delightful.
top_reviews.review: Just off one of the busy main streets is this haven of tranquillity, which is immaculately kept. Apart from the houses there are 2 churches, one English (closed) and the other Catholic, which we were able to visit. Some parts are cordoned off, which is entirely understandable as people are living there. There is no entrance fee, so it can get a little busy, though I believe visitor numbers are controlled by wardens. Not to be missed.

name: De Gooyer Windmill
category: Points of Interest & Landmarks Architectural Buildings

name: De 9 Straatjes
description: This neighborhhod of "nine little streets" is full of quirky stores selling clothing, books, art, food and lots more.

name: H'ART Museum
description: As the Hermitage Amsterdam, and now as H’ART Museum, we have always housed some of the most unique and famous art, from present day to antiquity. Connecting the art world in new ways and bringing it to Amsterdam for everyone to enjoy. Now we form a unique global art collective together with world-renowned international partners The British Museum, Centre Pompidou, and SAAM (Smithsonian American Art Museum), which brings the UK, France, USA, and the Netherlands together as never before. We want to inspire people through powerful, relevant, and heartfelt art.

name: Amsterdamse Bos
description: Covering an area of almost 1000 hectares, the Amsterdamse Bos is one of the largest city parks in Europe. It contains 150 indigenous species of trees and over 200 species of birds. The park sits to the South of central Amsterdam and can easily be reached by bike, tram or metro from the city center.

name: Body Worlds
description: Gunther von Hagens’ BODY WORLDS: The Happiness Project in the heart of Amsterdam tells the amazing story of our own body and the impact of happiness on our health. More than 200 anatomical specimens of real human bodies show the complexity, resilience and vulnerability of the body. Join the 40 million people around the world who have already seen the exhibition and been on this fascinating voyage of discovery through the human body.

top_reviews.title: Interesting and fun learning experience
top_reviews.review: Very interesting and great way to get to experience the human body. We enjoyed seeing the insides of our fellow man. Didn't think it was gory or grotesque and I would take my kids here if they were with. Only minus is there could have been more, we were definitely not "done" after walking through the entire exhibit.

top_reviews.title: Incredible - Eye opening!
top_reviews.review: Incredible exhibit with really eye opening displays. Taking the time to read all of the information really takes the purpose of this place to another level. Only point to note - my partner and I read all the information and were here for about 1.5 hours so don’t plan to make a visit for a whole morning or afternoon.

top_reviews.title: Really interesting!
top_reviews.review: Really interesting and informative exhibition! We were worried it was going to be quite gimmicky but it was the complete opposite! Each floor had different focus points and a good variety of plastinations to view and written information. I would definitely recommend a visit here when Amsterdam.

top_reviews.title: Very interesting
top_reviews.review: My friend and I came across Bodyworld whilst walking through Amsterdam, I had heard of this place and wanted to take a look. Arjen on the door was very likeable and funny, he encouraged us to go inside and very glad we did, it was very informative. We took a lift up to the sixth floor and worked our way down through the floors. I learned how the brain deteriorates through dementia, saw the workings of new hip joints and knee joints, the difference between an ordinary spleen and an enlarged spleen, and how important it is not to smoke, to be healthy and most importantly, to be happy! Very interesting place, there's something for everyone to learn

top_reviews.title: Great for all ages.
top_reviews.review: We visited Body Worlds with our kids (aged 9, 13, 14, 15, 16). It was interesting for all of us! Beautiful and intriguing. The body scan at the end was a great addition. Tks Arjen for your recommendation.

top_reviews.title: Informative and Fascinating
top_reviews.review: We were here in September and just turned up and got tickets on the door, no queue and not busy inside. A great exhibition that is well presented and very informative, take as long as you want with each floor explaining a different aspect of the body. Take time to read the inspirational quotes and don't forget to do the body analysis at the end and get your free print out.

top_reviews.title: Amazingly insightful, interesting, informative. Recommend for all ages.
top_reviews.review: Such a fun-tastic tour of the museum! I expected much less, and I was amazed to see how much I didn't know, how much I've learned a out the human body, thing I should have known a long time ago. Thank you, Arjen, for recommending us to go inside. Thank you!

top_reviews.title: Fascinating and educational
top_reviews.review: Both my partner and I loved our visit. It was so interesting to see so much of the inner workings of the human body, and the size and shape of numerous organs, blood vessels etc. It was sometimes annoyingly rowdy in some rooms with people talking loudly so we hovered at displays waiting for quieter times as there’s a lot to read and absorb. Grateful thanks to people/families who donated bodies to provide a learning experience for us. We spent 2 hours in the museum as we had somewhere else to be, but would’ve stayed longer had we been able to.

top_reviews.title: Eye opening
top_reviews.review: Visited Body Worlds as part of our Amsterdam trip. We had one of these in London but it suddenly closed down so never got to visit it. The price of our visit was £19.21 each. The experience it self is amazing and definitely an eye opener. You can see the multiple working ways of the human body from the veins, the nervous system to the brain. The way the bodies have been positioned is amazing and very interesting to see. A word of warning, there is a part within here with shows bodies of babies and the functions of pregnancy etc. There are also examples of a foetus from 9 weeks through the end of pregnancy. I know some people may find this distressing; as i witnessed whilst i was there however it is also very interesting to see but i guess it’s worth knowing as that is not really advertised. When i visited once i don’t think i would visit again unless a new exhibition opens.

top_reviews.title: Fantastic experience with my mum
top_reviews.review: Had an amazing experience!!!! It said the average experience is 1 hr or an 1hr and a half, we spent 3 hrs in there as there was just so much to read and see!!! If you're into science and how the body works this is defiantly something you should see. I probably wouldn't take kids with me as they'd get bored but it all depends on what you've got planned for the day. ARJEN answered all queries and discoveries we had adding to the experience further.

name: St. Nicholas Basilica
category: Historic Sites Religious Sites Churches & Cathedrals
address: Prins Hendrikkade 73, 1012 AD Amsterdam The Netherlands

name: Concertgebouw
description: The Royal Concertgebouw is one of the world's most famous concert halls renowned for its exceptional acoustics. With 700 concerts a year the Concertgebouw offers a varied programme featuring leading international musicians, orchestras, and conductors. The hall functions as a home base for the Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra, one of the very best orchestras in the world. Time and time again, critics have lauded its unique sound, which clearly stands out among thousands of others. Behind-the-scenes tours provide a look into the concert hall's rich history. There are scheduled tours three times a week and for groups available on request. From September to June at 12:30pm. Every Wednesday, there is a free 30 minute concert in the Concertgebouw. Due to the popularity of these concerts it is recommended to arrive at least 45min before the concert.
address: Concertgebouwplein 10 Museum Quarter, 1071 LN Amsterdam The Netherlands

top_reviews.title: A must do in Amsterdam for concert lovers
top_reviews.review: Concert was fantastic. Seats -4 th row orchestra were inexpensive for where they were as compared to Lincoln center. Dinner at Lies beforehand was superb and we just walked internally to the concert. Price fixed three course dinner is highly recommended.

top_reviews.title: Christmas is coming soon!!!
top_reviews.review: I like to come here for a concert every now and then, sometimes alone or otherwise with my partner. To sit here, enjoying a nice concert, i find it to be a great and wonderful cultural experience. I would definitely recommend this place, purely as a devoted classical music fan. For me personally, the classical music scene in Amsterdam is one of the highlights of this, if i may say so, really great and still very open minded world-class city!!!

top_reviews.title: Great concert space
top_reviews.review: Number 3 concert hall in the world for acoustics and it is clear that it deserves the rating. Beautiful architecture and well laid out space with plenty of areas to congregate and each to access and depart. No bad sight lines or columns to interfere with the view. Highly recommend attending a performance if you have the chance.

top_reviews.title: The Big Concert Hall
top_reviews.review: This big classical music concert hall is located on the Amstel River and looks splendid both day and night. It is one of the most memorable buildings in town, seen well from bridges and from canal boats. If you take a canal cruise, you will see it.

name: RAI Amsterdam
description: Bringing people together, connecting and inspiring them by organising and facilitating meaningful encounters. We do this from our multifunctional exhibition and conference centre on Europaplein in Amsterdam, as well as elsewhere in the world where we operate.

name: Museum Vrolik
description: The Museum Vrolikianum was the private anatomical collection of the Amsterdam anatomists Gerard (1775-1859) and Willem Vrolik (1801-1863). After their deaths, the collection was further expanded by other Amsterdam anatomists. The human body is the central focus in Museum Vrolik. What do we look like on the inside? What diseases did people suffer from in the past? Skeletons and wet specimens show the devastating effects of diseases like rickets (English disease), TBC and syphilis. Congenital malformations are also on display, such as cyclopia and conjoined twins. Museum Vrolik has a large collection of animal anatomy as well.

name: WONDR Experience
description: WONDR is an immersive pop-up experience that blends visual magic with boundless creativity. A confetti- sprinkled playground of color and sensation designed by some of Amsterdam's most creative minds. Our interactive exhibit is a place for people of all ages to connect with each other and explore: dance, sing, paint, swim, make new friends and have a great time.
category: Art Galleries Speciality Museums Art Museums

name: Dam Square
description: All roads lead to Dam Square, the real heart of Amsterdam, where The Royal Palace, the Nieuwe Kerk and the War Memorial overlook this vast and bustling open space.

top_reviews.title: It Is a Dam Large Square!!
top_reviews.review: Dam Square and Dam Palace lie in the heart of Amsterdam, at the original location of the dam in the Amstel River. It is a large, bustling square where people gather, and there are numerous shops and cafes that line the square. There is also a National Monument an important memorial to World War II. Dam Palace, Dam Square, Dam pictures and YES, my husband had to make some dam jokes!

top_reviews.title: Busy
top_reviews.review: Dam Square is like the Times Square of Amsterdam, minus all the crappy traffic and people. It's a gorgeous, wide open area with several popular places such as Royal Palace, Madame Tussauds, and Bijenkorf. There are many shops and places to eat/drink. There is also easy access to a lot of the major trams that spreads throughout the city. This is a great place to walk in the middle of and just take it all in. The people, the birds, and sometimes performances (even soccer games!) are just brings a great vibe and gives you that "I'm Here" feeling.

top_reviews.title: Not my favorite spot in Amsterdam, but iconic nonetheless
top_reviews.review: Always busy, always crowded, but iconic nonetheless. The facade of the Royal Palace is impressive as well as the grand dame of Amsterdam hotels, Grand Hotel Krasnopolsky, facing the National Monument, which is not exactly a masterpiece. My favorite corner in Dam Square is the beautiful austere 15th-century Gothic revival masterpiece, the Nieuwe Kerk, which is one of the oldest churches in Amsterdam.

top_reviews.title: Amsterdam was founded on this site.
top_reviews.review: In the XIII century, there was no square here, but there was an empty place where freshly caught fish were sold. Around 1270, local fishermen built a dam and a lock on the Amstel, and a fishing village of a dozen houses was named Amsteledamme. Now it is the symbolic center of Amsterdam. The square has two dominants facing each other - the Royal Palace and the national monument in honor of those killed in World War II. Despite the name, King Willem-Alexander does not live here, his residence is in The Hague. However, official events with his participation may take place here. But the weddings of the monarchs take place in the neighboring building- the Nieuwe Kerk, facing the square from the side. On the opposite side, where the national monument is located, there is a large department store De Bijenkorf, the Madame Tussaud Museum, the Grand Hotel Krasnapolsky and Hotel Twenty Seven. All these buildings were built at different times in different styles, but strangely enough, such eclecticism doesn`t spoil the Dam Square...

top_reviews.title: Unassuming square
top_reviews.review: There is an ambience about the space as people hustle and bustle by. The Riyal Palace is being cleaned and looks underwhelming which takes something from the square. There are shops and restaurants dotted around but it lacked any real wow factor.

top_reviews.title: Busy place central Amsterdam
top_reviews.review: We have been in a hotel directly a the Dam Place. From here you can walk in all directions and all streets will ending finally at the Dam. ( like all streets leading to Rome ) The Dam has the royal palace, the war monument, shops, coffees and at the other side the red light district. Always a lot of people there.

top_reviews.title: Very Busy Square
top_reviews.review: A very busy but central square on the Damrak. You’ll find the Royal Palace, NienweKerk and National Monument here and all are architecturally impressive. Madame Tussaud’s is also here along with numerous shops and restaurants, hence the busy nature. Well worth a visit!

top_reviews.title: Classic town square
top_reviews.review: Nice open space near the Royal Palace. Always crowds and always some forms of entertainment going on. The historic significance of the square is really not fully evident unless you tour the adjacent sites and hear about their relationship to the square.

top_reviews.title: Can Be Chaotic
top_reviews.review: One of the centers of the city and you will surely pass through here. Several important buildings are here and you are in the middle of all the shopping. But this is also the middle of all the tourism, so be prepared for wandering crowds. Some construction going on during our visit, making it a bit of chaos.

top_reviews.title: Okay but no wow factor
top_reviews.review: Square itself was reasonably quite but surrounding street were particularly busy. Nothing special but surrounded by historic buildings, would probably have been more interesting for us if we'd been part of a tour. Felt the square was let down by having two burger vans plying their trade at opposite corners of the square.

name: Royal Palace Amsterdam
description: The Royal Palace Amsterdam is in use by the Dutch Royal House. Most of the year, the Royal Palace is alsof open for visitors. You are welcome to discover the rich history and interior of this magnificent building in the heart of Amsterdam. Visitors are welcome to discover the building's rich past and legacies left by it's successive occupants - as Amsterdam's Town Hall for 150 years, the French Royal and Imperial Palace for 5 years and the Palace of the House of Orange for the past two centuries. The Royal Palace was built in the seventeenth century as the Town Hall of Amsterdam, after a design by Jacob van Campen. It's paintings and sculptures were made by some of the most distinguished artists of the time and allude to the city's influence and prosperity in the Dutch Golden Age. In 1808 Louis Napoleon, brother of the French Emperor Napoleon Bonaparte, became King of Holland and converted the Town Hall into a Palace. The superb collection of Empire furniture, clocks and chandeliers date from that period. The collection of Empire furniture is one of the best preserved and most complete collections in the world. The rooms in the Palace are decorated with artworks from the collection of the House of Orange-Nassau Historic Collections Trust. Many paintings show the various members of the family of Orange-Nassau
address: Nieuwezijds Voorburgwal 147, 1012 RJ Amsterdam The Netherlands

top_reviews.title: Clever guided Tour
top_reviews.review: We really enjoyed the tour. The guided digital tour is amazing and you can go at your own pace listening and watching in as much detail as you like. Fascinating to see the rooms used by world leaders as well as the history and amazing art especially the sculptures. This is so integral to Dutch history and Dam Square so a clever tour to let you see so much when it’s not in Royal use. Stunning.

top_reviews.title: Interesting Visit
top_reviews.review: Well worth a visit when in Amsterdam. The central hall upstairs is an impressive highlight and the audio guide is interesting and informative. The only thing that was slightly annoying was that you had to wait in queues to look in rooms behind plastic screens but we visited on Xmas eve so quite busy so maybe at quieter times it’s not as noticeable.

top_reviews.title: Great Palace visit
top_reviews.review: A lovely Royal Pace that was formerly a City Hall. Good audio guide that you can do key bits or whole Palace. The entrance hall is especially good as ate the bedrooms and throne room.

top_reviews.title: Underwhelming
top_reviews.review: Audio guide tour was included in a very reasonable ticket of 12 euro. The whole tour was about an hour. Lots of rooms were peak-inside only through the door; no entry. Audio guide was quite minimalistic. If you run out of things to do it’s a good place to visit. This is our fourth trip to Amsterdam and first time we did it.

top_reviews.title: Interesting
top_reviews.review: The visit with the audio guide, free and essential, is very interesting. No need to really book, you can come at any time, and you are very well received. 23 pieces to see, it takes an hour and a half. There is a cloakroom downstairs, free, but not self-service.

top_reviews.title: Excellent value fascinating tour
top_reviews.review: This is a must see in Amsterdam. Although the exterior looks a little worn, the interior is a fascinating tour of the history of the palace and Dutch history. You actually get to see the famous balcony, throne rooms and where the transfer of power between Dutch monarchs takes place. I was over two hours going around. At 12.50 euros it represents excellent value for money. This and a canal boat tour would make for a lovely day in Amsterdam.

top_reviews.title: A must see!
top_reviews.review: The most amazing thing I got to experience in Amsterdam was The Palace. Beautiful! Absolutely lost for words. Very affordable ticket prices! You are also able to get a headset for free which you defiantly need as there is no other information at the palace. You have to leave your bags etc however, they hold them for free. No eating/drinking. You can take photos but with no flash and video recording is not allowed.

top_reviews.title: Very interesting
top_reviews.review: Felt this was worth a visit. The audio tour made it better, and more interesting then perhaps just looking would have (is included in the ticket) and they are slick getting you set up in your preferred language. Talks about the architecture, sculptures, flooring, rooms, furniture, paintings including up to modern day with King William. Definitely a good visit

top_reviews.title: Far exceeded my expectations
top_reviews.review: This palace was once known as the 8th Wonder of the World. When looking at it from the outside, while in the City Center Square, the exterior looks like it needs some power washing or something. But once you go inside and pay the ticket fee and get your audio tour guide, it is filled with extraordinary architecture, art and history. I would definitely recommend visiting the Royal Palace and Amsterdam.

top_reviews.title: An enjoyable way to spend an hour
top_reviews.review: I had an hour to kill before catching the Eurostar from Centraal Station so I took a tour of the Royal Palace in Dam Square. As with everywhere I visited in the Netherlands there is really good bag storage. You really need the audio tour, as there are no labels on things and you can only see some rooms from a barrier at the door. In spite of this I found the tour quite enjoyable. The audio tour is very well done and for most rooms there are additional sections specifically for the paintings. The highlight is the final room on the tour, where the judges used to sit and punishments were dealt out. Good for an hour or so.

name: Hortus Botanicus
address: Plantage Middenlaan 2A, 1018 DD Amsterdam The Netherlands

top_reviews.title: Beautiful well appointed botanical garden
top_reviews.review: Hortus Botanicus is not huge, but the hothouses full of lush tropical greenery are lovely. One hothouse even has butterflies. The garden is more beautiful in spring of course, when its beautiful flowers are in full bloom. As planned, I went to their cafe, where I enjoyed sublime apple crumb cake with raisins and a cup of turmeric tea in gorgeous surroundings.

top_reviews.title: An oasis of calm!
top_reviews.review: A lovely, small botanical gardens. Beautiful glasshouse with three climate zones. Went in winter so the outside gardens were not doing much but I’m sure would be lovely in the spring. Very nice cafe/restaurant too. Very peaceful place.

top_reviews.title: A botanical wonderland!
top_reviews.review: It is truly a botanical wonderland! As I walked through the different sections of the garden, I was amazed by the variety of plants from all over the world. From tropical rainforests to arid deserts, the garden has recreated different ecosystems, making it a truly immersive experience. Apart from the impressive flora, the hortus botanicus also boasts a stunning butterfly greenhouse. Walking through this enclosed space, surrounded by a multitude of colorful butterflies, felt like a magical journey. Not only is the hortus botanicus a romantic spot for a first date, especially in the evening with its illuminated pathways and hot chocolate, but it is also a perfect destination for families. The enchanting atmosphere of the garden gives me the tingles, and I am already looking forward to my next visit.

top_reviews.title: Quiet and Lovely Botanical Garden
top_reviews.review: A perfect place to visit for peace and quiet. Although I visited in February (and am sure it's even more amazing in the summer and fall), I was impressed by the careful layout of the grounds and the variety of flora and fauna. There's a lovely gift shop and cafe and several greenhouses.

top_reviews.title: Small well manicured garden
top_reviews.review: The botanical garden was interesting but smaller than I expected. They are working on a significant greenhouse expansion that will definitely increase the size of the garden. The palm greenhouse was unique with some palms you don’t frequently see and some that are really old. My wife especially enjoyed the butterfly greenhouse. There were about 4 species of butterflies active.

top_reviews.title: Interesting history
top_reviews.review: After visiting Kuekenhof gardens, this was a little underwhelming. The best part was the cool glasshouse with tropical plants. The building is really magical. The gardens were pleasant to walk through. Nothing was in English so I didn’t know what I was looking at. I did appreciate it for its historical significance.

top_reviews.title: Nice way to spend a couple of hours
top_reviews.review: Lovely gardend with plenty to see and information on each area of the garden. There were some beautiful Tulip displays which were definitely one of the highlights. The greenhouse is under renovation but you can walk around parts of it. We also had a lovely lunch in the cafe and that is definitely worth visiting alongside the gardens.

top_reviews.title: A nice respite
top_reviews.review: Very nice compact gardens. Perfect for a walk around with children or alone. No admission charge with the IAmsterdam card. Loved the butterfly area and the fact that most plants were labelled. Located very near a stop on Tram 14

top_reviews.title: For the butterflies 🦋🦋 alone it's worth the visit!!! Beautiful botanical gardens!
top_reviews.review: What a BEAUTIFUL place!! The plants and the butterfly enclosure were so lovely. Allow at least an hour if tight for time. Went here after dropping luggage off in Centraal station, caught the 14 tram to Hortus Botanical garden. So glad we did!!!

top_reviews.title: Visit to Hortus Botanicus
top_reviews.review: We had very high expectations and so initially we had a bit of disappointment. It's made in a very small area and so sprawling gardens were missing there. But then it had amazing varieties of plants few of which were very old. We also saw carnivorous plants like pitcher plant etc.about which we had only read in books. Then we enjoyed the soup in the Cafe there, which is set amidst beautiful green plants. Overall we enjoyed the visit.

name: Willet-Holthuysen Museum
description: Visitors can tour this 17th-century canal-side house in Amsterdam, which is filled with furnished period rooms and works of art that were donated by the owner Louisa Willet-Holthuysen to the city in 1895.

top_reviews.title: Lovely private home museum and gardens in the middle of the town.
top_reviews.review: Lovely small museum that is a private home preserved and also offers rotating museum exhibits within the home and gardens. It's easy to see in less than an hour and interesting to see how the family lived and the detail of the building, the art and the gardens. If you want a smaller experience than the huge museums and like seeing historically preserved homes, this is a must see!

top_reviews.title: Unexpected tour
top_reviews.review: Stumbled across this house on our way to rembrandtplein. Decided to go in and enjoyed looking around. Audio is a must. Can’t beat a good tour. Interesting that a previous curator seems to have got rid of a few things 🤔🤔

top_reviews.title: Beautiful mansion and garden
top_reviews.review: After the Stromma cruise I felt rested enough to walk very fast to the Huis Willet Holthuysen from the Rijksmuseum and see the beautiful mansion in 45 minutes before closing. It was so worth it! The interior and the garden are truly spectacular, but to say that the ANONHI exhibit “She who saw beautiful things” impressed me would be a lie: this is not my type of art.

top_reviews.title: Behind the house facade
top_reviews.review: Get inside an 18th century Holland house? This house is a great opportunity:) Take your audio guide and enjoy the whole house from the garden behind the house, to the kitchen, and to the luxury apartments on top. For teens up to 18 the entrance is free.

top_reviews.title: A unique museum in Amsterdam
top_reviews.review: I went on a weekend trip to Amsterdam and didn't plan my stay. When I searched for interesting places near my hostel I found the pipe museum. Even as someone who just started pipe smoking it was a very interesting visit. I felt very welcome. The museum itself is a collection of pipes, there is nothing to read so someone was there to guide me. The tour through the small house was very interesting and the guide was very helpful in answering questions also talking about his own experiences and preferences concerning pipes which made the tour more of a dialogue which I really enjoyed. All in all I had a great time and would recommend ta visit. Since it is also very central and not a big museum you don't have to plan your whole day around it.

top_reviews.title: Our visit to the Pipe museum
top_reviews.review: What an absolute gem of a place! The diversity, history and artwork of the pipes is stunning. For a small fee you get to see the museum on the 1st floor where the curator will talk you through the different areas that the pipes came from, what they are made of and their significance socially. It was extremely interesting.

top_reviews.title: A hidden gem
top_reviews.review: My friend and I were looking to visit a less famous museum in Amsterdam as we've been here numerous times. We came across this museum without expecting much but we were surprised by how interesting it is! We had a guided tour in french which made the experence much better as we had the full explanation about the history of pipes. Definitely worth the visit.

top_reviews.title: Interesting guided tour around the museum floor, beautiful collection.
top_reviews.review: I came in the late afternoon hours ans started the guided tour at the upper floor. The pipe collection spans from the ancient civilizations and cultures of different ethnic groups and people, through the industrial and the colonial eras and to these days. You will here stories about pipe related rituals and what it symbolizes each one of them. You can take pictures inside, and even have a photo with a giant smoking pipe. It is fun and interesting history-wise, even for a non-smoker like me.

top_reviews.title: Smoking my pipe
top_reviews.review: I really enjoyed visiting the museum. The staff was very nice and friendly. My guide was a very professional young man. The diplay is very nice and also the house where the museum actually is. I think they should promote this museum much more. A pity that some books are only in dutch, but most of their materials it's in english. Some would say they promote 'bad habit', but smoking it's something concerning our culture and mankind.Anyway I would say a visit to this museum it is a must. It's located in one of the nicest canal in Amsterdam and it won't take you much time to visit it. At 12 o'clock I was the first visitor, and I took some great photos. Nice postcards and books are available for sell.

name: The Jordaan
description: This charming neighborhood is Amsterdam's Greenwich Village, with its narrow alleys, leafy canals lined with 17th-century houses, quirky specialty shops, cafes and designer boutiques.

top_reviews.title: Charming walks
top_reviews.review: Lovely shops, charming strolls around to see the neighbourhood. Great restaurants and places to eat. Easy to walk out and hop on a tram or bus to go elsewhere in the city. We stopped in the mechanical toy store with our kids and they loved it - spent quite a while playing with toys there.

top_reviews.title: Beauty, history, and culture
top_reviews.review: The Jordaan is a charming neighborhood in Amsterdam with picturesque canals, historic buildings, and a lively local vibe. Highlights include the Noordermarkt, Anne Frank House, and numerous cafes and art galleries. Don’t miss the Dutch apple pie and local cheeses. A must-visit for its beauty, history, and culture.

top_reviews.title: Upscale, Charming, Quiet
top_reviews.review: This is the cool neighborhood, a great place to stay in a hotel or to live. Charming canal houses and some very good restaurants. It is clean and safe and a bit away from the honky tonk areas that are clogged with tourists. Come and take a stroll, have a coffee.

top_reviews.title: Lovely stroll
top_reviews.review: While exploring Amsterdam by use of a hop-on-hop-off bus and boat, it was easy to get to a number of places to explore on foot. The Jordaan neighborhood was very beautiful, and we were able to explore many streets. As other reviewers have said, it is much quieter than Amsterdam city center, and it is even a little more picturesque. We were lucky to be there on a clear, sunny day with no agenda. Great walk.

top_reviews.title: Best to explore if you need quiet
top_reviews.review: Although this was the best spot in the central Amsterdam, I still was not as impressed as in Leiden. The worst are cars parked along the canals. But if you're there for the first time, visit the Jordaan: it's quiet, clean and cozy.

top_reviews.title: Must-Visit Neighborhood in Amsterdam
top_reviews.review: The Jordaan is a beautiful and charming part of Amsterdam. With its picturesque canals, historic buildings, and cozy cafes, it offers a true local experience. Wandering the narrow streets and discovering hidden courtyards was a highlight of my trip. The neighborhood has great shops, markets, and delicious food options. It's a perfect spot to explore and enjoy the city's authentic vibe.

name: Anne Frank House
description: The Anne Frank House (Dutch: Anne Frank Huis) is a museum dedicated to Jewish wartime diarist Anne Frank. The building is located on a canal called the Prinsengracht, close to the Westerkerk, in central Amsterdam in the Netherlands. As a visitor, you experience this story through a audio tour (there is also one especially for children), quotes, photos, videos, and original items. The Anne Frank House can only be visited with an online ticket for a specific date and time. These are only on sale through the website of the Anne Frank House: https://www.annefrank.org Please note that many invalid tickets are offered online. Also via URLs and websites similar to the one of the Anne Frank House. Commercial parties offering Anne Frank House tours do not provide access to the Anne Frank House.
address: Prinsengracht 263 - 267 Museum Entrance Westermarkt 20, 1016 DK Amsterdam The Netherlands

top_reviews.title: This place must be on your bucket list. If you have any humanity at all.
top_reviews.review: I had read the book, seen documentaries and films both good and bad, now I wanted to see where it all happened. First challenge was booking a ticket. The slots fill up very quickly and can only be booked online so DO NOT HANG AROUND! The day we were there was completely sold out. You get a perspective on why the Franks decided to hide. "Jews must turn in their bikes. Jews are not allowed to ride on Trams. Jews are not allowed in swimming pools. Jews must do their shopping between 1500 and 1700 each day. Jews are not allowed to sit in their gardens after 2000. Jews are not allowed to carry flowers. Jews are not allowed in Cinemas"...the list goes on. Without any spoilers you get a flavour of the characters of the people. The most important and moving part was they fully acknowledged the part and the tremendous risks taken by the helpers, Johanes Kleinman, Jan Gies, Miep Gies, Bep Voskuil and Victor Kugler. If they had been caught they would have been shot if they were lucky. I thought I knew the story. I was wrong. It was incredibly moving. Most of all it showed the power of hope, and the strength of the human spirit in adversity. If you don't come out of there a different person you are not a human being.

top_reviews.title: Must see!!
