top_reviews.review: We booked the group tour on the Anne Frank House website. Very moving and emotional experience. I would suggest to watch the new series "A Small Light", watching this before our visit was a real insight to this tragic story.

top_reviews.title: A Solemn Glimpse into History at Anne Frank House
top_reviews.review: Visiting Anne Frank House in Amsterdam was deeply moving. It's not just a museum, but a silent witness to a heartbreaking history. Walking through the rooms, you can picture the fear and hope that once lived within these walls. It’s beautifully kept and tells a story that we all need to hear, to remember the dark times and ensure they never happen again. However, some review I've read are madness! This isn’t a place for thrill-seekers or fun photos. It’s a place to quietly reflect on a young girl’s life and the terrible events of the past. Make sure to book your tickets well in advance, it will be sold out weeks in advance and "walk-ins" don't happen.

top_reviews.title: A Must See
top_reviews.review: The Anne Frank House was a bucket list for me, as I taught the Diary of Anne Frank for many years. The experience was so sad, knowing what these people had to endure. I recommend this experience to everyone, as it is a very important part of our history.

top_reviews.title: An “Attraction” Worth the Wait
top_reviews.review: Feels a bit disrespectful writing a review of this “attraction”, but really wanted to make this visit. Yes there is a new visitor centre built next door I assume to cope with the visitor numbers, of which we added 3 people to those numbers. Bags and coats can be stored in lockers, included in the entrance charge. The inevitable queuing system works well and gives you time to read the captions and listen to the audio tours, included in the cost. I found the tour moving, Anne’s story was a story I’ve heard all my life, this was a bit of a pilgrimage of sorts. We later found out on a separate unrelated tour that the Gestapo headquarters in Amsterdam were, in WWII, just around the corner on the same block… History helps us avoid the mistakes of the past.

top_reviews.title: Haunting
top_reviews.review: The Anne Frank House Tour was a deeply moving and educational experience. Walking through the historic annex where Anne Frank and her family hid during World War II was both poignant and thought-provoking. The tour was well-organized, and our guide was knowledgeable, providing insightful commentary about Anne's diary and the events of that time. This visit was a powerful reminder of the importance of tolerance, understanding, and the need to remember history. A must-visit for anyone interested in the human story behind the Holocaust.

top_reviews.title: Anne Frank Hiuse: So earring and Interesting Experience
top_reviews.review: I was surprised at the modern facade. Behind this building is the actual “house” in which the Frank family took refuge. I learned a lot about their ordeal and the facts of their 2 year hiding. The house is not wheel chair accessible or for the disabled. Their are a lot of stairs and at least one is similar to a ladder. There is a bookstore/gift shop at the end with bathrooms plus a small cafe. Cloakroom is free. You won’t be comfortable going up all the stairs with your coats and large bags.

top_reviews.title: Sobering. Well preserved. Actual notebooks can be viewed.
top_reviews.review: This museum is a sobering reminder of how badly a society can deteriorate when driven by a philosophy of hate. I am grateful that the house/annex has been so well preserved and that our visit allowed us to see a few of Anne Frank's actual notebooks. Climbing the same steep, narrow steps, holding the same handrails, and walking the same floors where the family hid for those years was inspiring for us. It is difficult to imagine the fear and anxiety that permeated those rooms during 1942-4.

top_reviews.title: A sobering journey
top_reviews.review: A sobering journey of a young girls life, or lack of. The narrative told the story well. Some steep stair cases to climb so take care. The original features take you back to the time Anne and her family lived here and made you imagine them being used. I would have given it 5 stars but I was a bit disappointed that photographs were not permitted. Allow 1.5 hours.

top_reviews.title: A must visit while in amsterdam
top_reviews.review: This was an experience my husband wanted to do while in Amsterdam. As a mother with a 14 and 6 year old I was worried it would be a bit boring. How wrong was I. Everyone including my youngest enjoyed the tour. You are given head sets to talk you through each room you visit it's not overcrowded and you walk at your own pace. We all learnt alot and I would highly recommend doing this while in amsterdam. Not allowed to take photos so can't share any.

name: Rembrandts Amsterdam Experience
description: Rembrandt is one of the most famous painters in the world. Step back in time to 1663 and visit his last studio. Rembrandt and his family take you on a fascinating journey through the painters’ life. You will be completely immersed into Amsterdam of the 17th century with the use of video projections, scents, music and 5D effects. Available in English and 7 other languages.
category: Speciality Museums Art Museums History Museums

top_reviews.title: Well presented
top_reviews.review: Very well planned. Audio device worked well and you could pause and resume easily throughout the tour to suit yourself. The house has been designed to replicate the original with well maintained artefacts to make it life like. The etching demonstration was well worth taking part in. Well priced at €17.

top_reviews.title: Thorough introduction to Rembrandt
top_reviews.review: We enjoyed this much more than we expected. The audio tour was very thorough and interesting, easy to use and you could pause it whenever you wanted or revisit areas. We saw Rembrandt’s paintings in the Rijkmuseum as well, but this audio tour gave me a much better idea of the techniques he used and even how he mixed his paints. It was also interesting to focus on his etchings, which I would probably not have bothered to look at otherwise. A good introduction to his life as well. Highly recommended.

top_reviews.title: A great introduction to the artist and city if you don’t know much about either.
top_reviews.review: This was a fun, little experience! It’s about 25mins and I felt that the price was appropriate. I did the VIP ticket which allowed me to choose a time 15 mins before the actual opening time. It included a little sweet snack and drink (water, soda, or juice. The experience includes two rooms that are immersive, but note it is not interactive. It was a great way to learn a little more about Rembrandt’s life within the context of the historical city of Amsterdam. It was very creative and well orchestrated. I recommend attending this towards the beginning of your stay as it will give you a basic level context and the history of 1600s Amsterdam. When you walk out and explore the canals and tight streets, you can start to imagine how it was during those times. And it did not take long, so you can really squeeze it into a larger itinerary, which is how I planned it.

top_reviews.title: Everything Rembrandt!
top_reviews.review: We purchased the Combo Reservation for the Rembrandt’s Amsterdam Experience and the Rembrandthuis Museum. Earlier in the morning, we had an interesting and informative tour at the museum. We weren't sure what to expect from the Rembrandt Experience. It is a well-done visual synopsis os Rembrandt’s life. It takes place in two rooms which envelope and draw you into his life. I will add that while we enjoyed it - it is very short, and I am not sure that it is worth the cost if you had not purchased the combo ticket.

top_reviews.title: Short but educational and great 5D experience. Totally worth it!!!
top_reviews.review: It was my very first trip to Amsterdam, from 26.12 - 28.12 and hopefully not my last one. So many places to visit and interesting things to see. My schedule was already full and I couldn't make it to Rembrandt's house. But Rembrandt's Experience was a great alternative and I'm glad that I choose this place. In a short amount of time (20-30 minutes), you'll learn the most important things about Rembrandt's life and family. The 5D experience will leave you speechless, especially if you haven't already experienced something similar before like me. Very educational, with great effects and setup that it will bring you with a short Time travel back to the Dutch Golden Age.

top_reviews.title: A fun experience!
top_reviews.review: We very much enjoyed our time at the Rembrandt’s Amsterdam experience. It is not a museum, it is more like an experience that you can immerse yourself in and enjoy the dramatic performance of Rembrandt and his story. At the end there was an option to create some fun AI Rembrandt style artwork, which we look back on with fondness. It was a great 1 hour fun which we were able to slot in whilst we were waiting for a restaurant booking. Thank you for the great experience.

name: Leiden Square (Leidseplein)
description: Planning a night out in Amsterdam? Head down to Leiden Square (Leidseplein,) which is known as the center of nightlife where you can choose from hundreds of bars, clubs, restaurants and discos that would suit every style and taste.

name: Straat Museum
description: STRAAT is the museum for street art and graffiti. In an enormous warehouse on the NDSM terrain in Amsterdam, more than 160 gigantic artworks are shown. These were created on-site by international artists. The collection is constantly growing, giving visitors the chance to catch artists painting live.

top_reviews.title: Not to be missed
top_reviews.review: Wow what an experience that shouldn’t be missed of anyone’s list visiting Amsterdam ! The adventure begins getting to the place, short ferry ride across from Amsterdam central station We have visited many graffiti exhibitions all over the world and this one stands close at the top as one of our favourites! The size of each piece of art is amazing and how it is displayed in the building A large variety of artwork to view and so much information shared on each piece We didn’t take a guided tour, we chose to work our way a round the exhibition by ourselves. It’s one of the first exhibitions visited not to have a big display of Banksy but in reality it has so many other artists artworks that’s just as incredible it wasn’t missed. The vibe is so relaxed and open it was an enjoyable visit Cafe was welcoming and in style to the exhibition Amazing visit and we will be back next time in the city.

top_reviews.title: Fabulous
top_reviews.review: This has got to be the best place to see this art form.. I can honestly say it's the longest I've stayed at a gallery. We loved it. Easy to hop on the free ferry at the back of the train station. Head for the building with the mural of Anne Frank on he side. A large factory building,well laid out. Some seating benches as you walk round and plenty of information as you walk round. Toilets on upper level as is the street food cafe.

top_reviews.title: Beautiful museum in unique setting
top_reviews.review: Even though I'm not crazy about graffiti art - visiting this museum was a great experience. The huge artworks, the unique space, and the colorfulness of everything made for a fantastic visual experience. I did not read the explanations of all the works, but the free phone-based audio tour gives some interesting explanations, and some large signs provide interesting clarifications about types of graffiti work, about the influence of graffiti on social campaigns etc.

name: De Krijtberg - Sint Franciscus Xaveriuskerk
description: Neo-gothic church from the 19th century, with a history that goes back to the 17thcentury era when the catholic was underground in the Netherlands.
category: Architectural Buildings Religious Sites Churches & Cathedrals

name: Heineken Experience
description: Go on a interactive journey at The Heineken Experience at Heineken's oldest brewery. The tour is mostly self-guided, with guides at certain key points. Here, you can learn about the history, gain insight into the brewing process, and customise your own Heineken bottle or glass at the souvenir shop. At the end of the tour, enjoy two Heinekens, and even get the chance to pour your own draught. – Tripadvisor

top_reviews.title: Really helpful staff
top_reviews.review: Arrived with my 78 year old mum after she'd walked some distance across Amsterdam as part of a tour. The queue to enter was huge and my mum was exhausted. The security guard approached us and found somewhere for mum to sit and rest. She was too tired to take the tour, but I was given priority entry so she didn't have to wait too long for me (we'd already got tickets ahead of the day). I have to say that the staff were excellent at this venue and I appreciated them being so accommodating. It's not easy travelling with an elderly relative and they made my visit so much easier. Thank you to you all.

top_reviews.title: The best time!!!!
top_reviews.review: Julieta is amazing she was so lovely and told us many facts and was so sweet to us!!! As was Valentina (I think that was her name) she game my friend who’s birthday it was a free drink! We love to see it! But either way. Great fun and such lovely staff!! So sweet. Highly recommend!!

top_reviews.title: First impressions count
top_reviews.review: First impressions were not good. Its quite badly organised and we were 30mins late into getting underway on the tour. However, things improved drastically and it turned out to be a really fun experience on our holiday. Even as a non-beer drinker, I really enjoyed the whole experience. The staff were great.

top_reviews.title: Touristy but actually a lot of fun (for two brothers in their 20s)
top_reviews.review: Had a great afternoon being guided through Heineken's history and the brewing process of its world-famous beer. Lots of opportunities for novelty photos and souvenirs. Some really good interactive/hands on moments. Definitely recommend matching with the canal cruise tour where you can sit back with a beer and learn more about Amsterdam from a fantastic guide.

top_reviews.title: I'm usually not a beer drinker but I had the best time on this tour
top_reviews.review: My family and I decided to do the VIP tour and it was the best decision! You get a personalized Heineken bottle with your name printed on it to take home with you, you have a tour guide taking you around so you can learn everything there is to know as well as avoid the huge crowds, and you get a private tasting in this very cool hidden room! You learn all about the brewing process and how the Heineken brand came to be, there are all of these interactive rooms throughout the tour, and at the end you also get another two free Heineken beers of your choice! Definitely a fun activity to do in Amsterdam.

top_reviews.title: Nice way to spend an afternoon and recommend rooftop bar
top_reviews.review: I’m not a beer drinker and was travelling on my own, yet I still enjoyed my experience here. I bought my ticket direct online from the website and arrived at the given time, you’ll still need to wait around 10-15 mins in the queue to get this scanned and get your tokens - in addition to the tokens you also get a free taster mid tiur. There are friendly and highly enthusiastic tour guides in key areas, lots of signage and things to look at with some history to Heineken thrown in. The ride isn’t a ride, it’s standing in a roo with big projections over screens and is a visual experience. The rooftop bar is worth it as you get lots of space to yourself and great views of the city, and it’s not crowded up there

top_reviews.title: Great time, and the rooftop bar was awesome
top_reviews.review: During my trip, I kept passing by and seeing this Heineken building. I had some time on my last day in Amsterdam, and decided to get tickets and give it a try. I'm so glad I did - this was so much fun! I thought it was really cool learning about the history of Heineken and seeing the traditional ways of brewing beer. The giant copper containers looked very steampunk to me. The electronic "ride" was a little cheesy, but afterward they gave us a beer tasting, which was neat. I got a ticket that included the rooftop bar. I'm not a big drinker, or a bar person, but the rooftop was really cool. They made cocktails out of the beer, and gave me tokens so I could relax there and try different drinks. Great vibes and great time overall. This ended up being one of my favorite things I did in Amsterdam!

top_reviews.title: Quick tour bed
top_reviews.review: My partner and I were able to snag tickets for the first tour of the day. We had a blast with all the interactive parts and enjoyed learning about the history and process of brewing beer. Highly recommend if you’ve got a few hours in the city and enjoy Heineken

top_reviews.title: Three Beer Tour
top_reviews.review: Went after recommendation, been to a few distillery tours so thought might be the same, but this brewery doesn’t brew beer here any more. The tour runs through the bowels of the old brewery, with a lot of self promotion (obviously) but still gives you a taste of what once went on. Three beers included at the price, one during the tour and two tokens to use at the bar. Top tip Heineken Silver has less alcohol, so stick to full fat Heineken… joking apart zero alcohol is available too. Took the rooftop experience, which gives great views. Of city from high up in a city/country with no hills. Only issue was, junior decided he only wanted to spend one token, not give it to me, and save beer token as a souvenir!

top_reviews.title: VIP Tour is the way to go!
top_reviews.review: We had fun on this private VIP Tour hosted by tour guide Maria from Athens. It’s not an active brewery but the history was interesting and there was only about 10-12 people on this 2 hour tour. The 2nd hour we went to a private bar (just our small group) for beer tastings with snacks. We tasted about 4 full glasses of beer and they give you two tokens to go to the crowded (not private) bar after the tour is over. Glad we paid extra for this tour. Worth the extra money.

name: The Amsterdam Dungeon
description: Amsterdam's murky past comes to life at the Amsterdam Dungeon * walk through Amsterdam’s sinister past * 500 years of history brought to you in about 80 minutes * meet our witch hunter, soul merchant and many other mouth breathers * go deep into the dungeon with (max) 29 other sinners * you are part of the show (or push another victim forward) * Scary True Stories and 'orrible Actors * English spoken… but also available in Dutch…. If you want to brag! * 10 years or younger? We wouldn’t do it, but that’s just an advise * Don’t tell anyone, but you can leave if you can’t take it anymore

top_reviews.title: Went here right after the wax museum, with wife and daughter.
top_reviews.review: The people putting this down are have unreasonable expectations. This is a show. It’s entertainment. This isn’t a history lesson. It’s a full 90 minute show. Compared to Madame Tussaud, this was a far better deal. We spent a whole 40 minutes at the wax museum. This was fun entertainment. Lots of laughs. Lots of fun. Lots of jump scares. They include people. Just be sure your English is good or some other language they provide tours for. Free glass of beer at the end.

top_reviews.title: That was Dam Scary 😰
top_reviews.review: Myself and my partner went here to experience the dark side of Amsterdam, we were not disappointed! From the start they set the mood and it only gets better from there! I screamed so loud in the Dutch mans scene! Would recommened to anyone who loves dark and scary experiences 😖

top_reviews.title: Amazing!
top_reviews.review: I totally loved it! My boyfriend isn’t really into scary stuff but he enjoyed it as well! It was funny and scary and we enjoyed a cup of Pop or Beer at the end. It’s an hour long and you get to do a lot as well. The characters involve you as well which makes this even better.

top_reviews.title: Meh
top_reviews.review: Having been to the ones in Edinburgh, London and Berlin previously we thought we would give this one a visit whilst we were there. Once you’ve been to one or two of them then a lot of the script is very similar if not the same so was a bit boring in parts - not really the actors/staff fault as they were pretty decent at what they do. Also compared to previous ones we have visited it just felt a little duller and lacking something. If you’ve been to others then I’d probably not bother but if you haven’t then it’s maybe worth a visit.

top_reviews.title: Amazing experience
top_reviews.review: It was an amazing experience, a little scary but not too much just perfect. The photos turned out amazing. It's great to buy them all in digital as me and my partner did. We really enjoyed our trip there, i think it was one of the greatest things we visited in Amsterdam. We loved it.

top_reviews.title: Great experience at Amsterdam Dungeon
top_reviews.review: The attraction was absolute fun. The actors were professional, funny and scary at the same time. The interactive show was hilarious. Plus we also managed to learn about Amsterdam's history!. My 13 years old daughter was literally glowing through the entire tour. I highly recommend it!

top_reviews.title: A must if you are in Amsterdam
top_reviews.review: It is a must if you are in Amsterdam. It is not scary at all if you enter with the mindset that it is a safe experience and nothing will happen to you. It is a funny, unexpecetd and really amazing experience. There are well prepared actors who are dressed according to the show and are very good at what they do. You pass from one room to another and live a different advenure in every room. It is an interactive experience where the public(visitors) are included, and is better enjoyed if everyone plays the part according to instructions they give you. The only bad thing is that it is not allowed to take photos or videos of your own inside, but at the entrance they take some funny pictures of you that you can purchase at the end of the experience.

top_reviews.title: I loved it - and I don't like horror
top_reviews.review: Hilariously funny. I thoroughly enjoyed this whole experience. There are parts where it is very dark, but the only thing tgat was scary was the thought of tripping in the dark. The rest is all entertaining fun. Great experience - worth every penny.

top_reviews.title: Fun time for most it's worth a stop to see
top_reviews.review: Fun time and they do a good job. It's a fun way to learn a little history and have some fun too. I've done these in several different cities they are all kind of the same but there's still fun to be had.

top_reviews.title: Spooky, Wry and Intense
top_reviews.review: From the moment I stepped inside the building, I could feel I was in for an adventure. The non-acting staff made sure of it. They had a peculiar sense of dry and dark humour which oddly enough, made me feel welcome. The set-up was brilliant. It was dark and eerie. The actors were incredibly talented. It was like I was transported to a different time. Jumpscares abound (I am an adrenaline junkie but the mild kind; I get spooked easily but I keep on wanting more. This is the perfect place for that). It was interactive-you get to be a part of the whole set which makes the experience even more unique and interesting. I absolutely loved it.

name: Portuguese Synagogue
category: Historic Sites Architectural Buildings Religious Sites
address: Mr. Visserplein 3, 1011 RD Amsterdam The Netherlands

name: Van Gogh Museum
description: Discover the world's largest collection of works by Dutch painter Vincent van Gogh, featuring masterpieces such as Sunflowers, The Potato Eaters, Almond Blossom and The Bedroom. Book your tickets online. Please consult the museum website for current opening hours.

top_reviews.title: Don’t miss Van Gogh museum
top_reviews.review: Wonderful museum. Beautiful art and lots of fascinating information on the artist. I did not know the depth of his mental illness, it’s sad that such a brilliant artist suffered so deeply. You have to buy your tickets in advance and select a time slot, but that enables you to enjoy the the art without the museum being overcrowded.

top_reviews.title: Emotional and iconic
top_reviews.review: I don't often review such iconic attractions because it seems obvious and it is, but it's so nicely laid out and entrance well managed too, good value for money and so so moving. Merchandise in the shop was excellent, and the Pokemon cross over exhibition wall is inspired, and hilarious. Having read about Vincent, I'm sure he'd love it too. We got offered 200 euro for our tickets, any pokemon fans reading this- do book in advance!

top_reviews.title: Very nice museum
top_reviews.review: This museum is such a beautiful build and is one of the best modern museums. It houses the paintings done by master artist Vincent Van Gogh and is mind-boggling. Each and every work of him has been displayed carefully, and one can appreciate the artefacts and the efforts of the museum. If one is travelling in Amsterdam, then it's a must visit place.

top_reviews.title: Van Gogh and go
top_reviews.review: Not to be overlooked ! When in Amsterdam this is a must see . The art of Vincent Van Gogh still is inspiring . Some of his work is like a small child with a box of crayons . While others are awe inspiring . Beauty is in the eye …….. Worth the time to learn about an artist who gave so much . A painting a day . More to learn than look . The art lives the artist passes .

top_reviews.title: Spectacular trip to Van Gogh Museum
top_reviews.review: Fortunately we reserved tickets well in advance. We had an ecstatic trip to the Van Gogh Museum. We also ate there: good coffee, bitterballen and shakshuka and mint tea with fresh mint. It is a lovely light-filled space and the paintings are beautifully displayed. To our great sorrow, we could not procure tickets to go again before we had to go home.

top_reviews.title: A Must GOGH!
top_reviews.review: We knew we wanted to experience the Van Gogh museum and it did not disappoint (but if you are looking for Starry Night - she is at the MOMA in NY). Learned a great deal about Van Gogh's life, his inspirations and his struggles. Such an inspiring day! Go EARLY to avoid huge crowds and make sure you buy a ticket in advance. I highly suggest doing the self guided audio tour - so much insight and information but at your own pace! Lots of great museums to explore while in Amsterdam!

top_reviews.title: A must-gogh!
top_reviews.review: I was pretty impressed with this museum. The facilities are great (free lockers for your bag) and headsets included for the self-guided tour. The tour was very informative and interesting. Highly recommend booking in advance as it seems to sell out pretty quickly.

top_reviews.title: A must see for art lovers
top_reviews.review: If you like Van Goch then this is a must. It has a great selection of Van Goch's works along with some of his contemporaries. Make sure you book as tickets sell out quickly & maybe book an early slot as it probably won't be so crowded. Despite it being busy, there was plenty of room to see all the wonderful paintings. We did not pay for the audio, there are plenty of information signs for each exhibit. A must see for art lovers.

top_reviews.title: Early time is quiet and peaceful. Look for tickets online the night before
top_reviews.review: Snagged a ticket online the evening prior to admission…. If possible get there early in the day… opens at 9. The AV rental ( 3.5 euros) well worth it and enhances your understanding. Take about two to three hours to see it all. When busy after 1030 the museum takes on a different ambience and becomes noisy and much harder to pause and view the artwork. There are two cafes..one serving lunch Well worth the visit.

top_reviews.title: Extensive collection of Van Gogh's Work
top_reviews.review: Excellent museum. Extensive collection of Van Gogh's work. Highly recommend buying tickets ahead of time as they were sold out on the day we went. Fortunately, we purchased our tickets a couple of months ahead.

name: Ripley's Believe It or Not!
description: Ripley's Believe It or Not! Amsterdam is the home of the bizarre and unbelievable! Over 500 crazy, yet true items that will for sure make you question your senses! Take a break from all the craziness in our Ripley's Lounge. Just a few minutes walking distance from The Central Station.
address: Dam 21 Dam Square, 1012 JS Amsterdam The Netherlands

top_reviews.title: Most interesting museum I've been to
top_reviews.review: Absolutely amazing museum! Full of so many random facts and artifacts that are genuinely interesting!!! We spent HOURS in this place... First time I've ever been to a museum and looked at literally everything. Highly recommend if you're in Amsterdam for a few days and want to do something different! Only downfall is there sheer amount of stairs, but that's Amsererdam for you.

top_reviews.title: Ripley’s
top_reviews.review: Probably the best thing that I done whilst in Amsterdam. Booked tickets online to beat the queues and went first thing before it got busy. I think all together we spent about three hours looking around all the attractions and exhibits. Well worth the money and would highly recommend visiting

top_reviews.title: Believe it or not - I loved this place
top_reviews.review: Went here as we had a couple of hours to spare. So glad we did, the exhibits are amazing in fact some are jaw dropping, couple of inter-actives didn’t work but that didn’t spoil the fun. Really interesting place and could easily spend more time there. Great gift shop too

top_reviews.title: Good
top_reviews.review: Was a last minute booking due to the weather! Expensive but glad we booked. Kids absolutely loved it! So much to see and do. Some of the exhibits weren’t working so that does need addressed and the girl at the beginning wasn’t the friendliest. However I would go back again.

top_reviews.title: A fabulous afternoon
top_reviews.review: We absolutely adored our time here and spent a very lengthy amount of time wandering around. You can really take it at your own pace and we actually learned loads about lots of different topics. The pictures we took here are really fond memories actually and it's an incredibly interactive exhibit with a lovely cafe at the top to relax afterwards. We would 100% recommend this place to anyone visiting Amsterdam - it was truly one of our highlights!

top_reviews.title: Excellent way to spend a couple of hours
top_reviews.review: This was our first activity when we arrived in Amsterdam. So in all fairness we were buzzing to go. This place didn't disappoint. I had pre booked tickets before I left the UK, so it was just a case of scanning my phone. There is so much to see and do here with quite a bit of interaction too. I was with my 12 year old grandson and he thought it was great. I was just surprised how many different floors there are! Everything is so well laid out, so even when its busy its easy to view all the exhibits. Highly recommend this place....even more so if its a wet miserable day

name: Hash Marihuana & Hemp Museum
description: Established by Ben Dronkers in 1985, the Hash, Marihuana &Hemp Museum is a tribute to the history of hemp and cannabis. What the museum offers its visitors is an insight into the history of one of the world's most commonly used drugs. The Hash, Marihuana & Hemp Museum also holds a carefully chosen selection of items from the world's largest collection of cannabis-related objects, the result of over a decade of collecting different kinds of objects associated with the cannabis plant. The Museum is not only of interest to cannabis users, but caters to those who are interested in learning about the plant, and even those who are simply curious about the relationship between its industrial and psychoactive varieties. With this extra-ordinary exhibition, the Hash, Marihuana & Hemp Museum definitely makes the list of Amsterdam attractions that tourists should not miss visiting.

top_reviews.title: ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐
top_reviews.review: An unconventional yet captivating experience, this museum offers a rare glimpse into the storied past of cannabis. While much of the subject matter may seem taboo, the exhibits thoughtfully unveil an array of insights seldom explored in mainstream historical accounts. From cultivation methods to cultural impacts across eras, the museum's meticulously curated displays shed light on a topic often obscured or oversimplified. An educational treasure trove for the curious mind, a visit promises to broaden perspectives and challenge preconceptions about a plant that has profoundly influenced human society. For those seeking an enlightening detour from conventional museums, this unique institution is a must-visit destination.

top_reviews.title: Geared Towards Beginners
top_reviews.review: The Hash Marihuana & Hemp Museum provides access to the museum next door. It's educational for newcomers to cannabis but lacks interactive features. Seasoned enthusiasts might find it less engaging and may prefer to skip this visit.

top_reviews.title: Interesting but small museum.
top_reviews.review: Very small museum, interesting and informative about the history of weed and hash. You get an audio guide at the start which makes walking around the small museum a lot more informative than just wondering around - so definitely grab one. Your ticket also gives you entry to the gallery down the road - this talks about the uses of Hash. This was very interesting and talks about the helpful and interesting ways the plant can be used in every day life. Overall informative and interesting museum.

top_reviews.title: Good, but not great.
top_reviews.review: Not sure what we expected, but there was A LOT more reading and listening than we anticipated. Learned a lot, but almost “too much” and ended up with “information overload”. We went with another couple who loved it, though, and they are much more involved in the “culture” than we are.

name: Museum of the Canals
description: Grachtenmuseum Amsterdam (The Museum of the Canals) is the starting point for visitors to Amsterdam! It is located in one of the most beautiful canalside houses. Grachtenmuseum Amsterdam introduces visitors to one of the best city development projects in the world: the 17th-century canals of Amsterdam. During your visit to the multimedia, interactive exhibition, you will travel in 40 minutes through 400 years of history.
category: Speciality Museums Art Museums History Museums

top_reviews.title: Interesting insights into the canals that define Amsterdam
top_reviews.review: The museum is in a house that is Tucktaway in one of the neighborhoods of Amsterdam. It takes about an hour for the entire tour, and it is self guided with audio assistive devices. I found the information to three dimensionalize the canals. How and why they were developed and what the current and future challenges will be for the canal system in Amsterdam Cost is about €17

top_reviews.title: A little gem of a museum
top_reviews.review: Visited the Canal museum on a rainy day with my 13 year old daughter. Was not as busy as many of the other museums we visited in Amsterdam which was refreshing. It is set in a stunning building with a beautiful garden. We both absolutely loved our visit, especially the interactive displays and innovative journey you are taken on through the history of Amsterdam. Highly recommend.

top_reviews.title: Clever bite-sized museum
top_reviews.review: Informative, bite-size museum that explains how Amsterdam was built. Unusual format for a museum. Money well spent on this museum. Try the quiz in the lobby waiting area before you go on the tour.

top_reviews.title: Great immersive museum
top_reviews.review: What a find! Really informative and immersive history of Amsterdam and its canals. We spent an hour there and thoroughly enjoyed it. Well worth spending the time and the money. It’s not large but really well thought out with models of houses and canals.

top_reviews.title: Charming and informative museum
top_reviews.review: This little museum tells the story of Amsterdam’s canals and its beautiful houses. The museum has some very well done virtual displays, informative videos, and interactive models. This is my third visit to Amsterdam, and I feel as though I learned more in the hour I spent here at this museum, than on other tours previously.

top_reviews.title: Lovely little museum
top_reviews.review: Lovely little museum takes about 1 hour 15 to see everything. Everything is present in a really innovative way. Not a huge amount of information but I really enjoy it. Helpful staff. Do the quiz in the waiting room while you wait.

top_reviews.title: An essential museum for any visitor to amsterdam.
top_reviews.review: An essential museum for any visitor to Amsterdam. We were told about this at the Houseboat museum otherwise would have completely missed this. It’s a very informative guided presentation that helps explain the history of the canals and then helps you to machinâtes and find your way around Amsterdam a lot better as a result!

top_reviews.title: Great way to understand Amsterdam’s historical development
top_reviews.review: This museum provides a great overview of the city and the canals that made her famous. Visitors are led from one room to the next, covering a variety of topics, to include the history of the building that houses the museum. If you’re at all interested in the history of Amsterdam, the Netherlands, and/or canals/inland shipping then you should add this museum to your visit list. Note: visitors are provided an audio guide in a variety of languages, so language barriers are not an issue.

top_reviews.title: Absolutely fascinating !
top_reviews.review: I wanted to try and understand the construction of the canals and the reclamation of land, that allowed Amsterdam to happen. Really interesting tour. It was quiet, I found it so fascinating, I asked if I could go back through for a second time .....

top_reviews.title: Fascinating - more museums should be like this
top_reviews.review: This little museum is great. It's not so much a history of the canals, more the history of Amsterdam through the story of the canals. We learnt so much about the history of the city. The exhibits are all audio visual. The large model house is intricate and beautiful. There are 5 guided rooms. Really recommend this.

name: Damrak
description: From bars and bicycles to cafes and erotic entertainment, you can find it all on this picturesque main street of Amsterdam.

top_reviews.title: Picturesque 'rak' in central Amsterdam
top_reviews.review: When arriving at Amsterdam Central Station it is the first main street on the city side. It used to be a canal or rather a "rak" in Dutch meaning a straight part of waterway in this case connecting Dam (square) with 'het IJ', the old harbour area. VOC ships used to moor here. Nowadays the "rak" is partly filled in to enable construction (Berlage Beurs and Bijenkorf supermarket), but closer to the station it is still open water where canal tours are on offer. A pity that most business is now geared to tourists like the Venus temple and many fast food outlets and restaurants.

top_reviews.title: Very Crowded Major Street
top_reviews.review: It's the major wide street that leads to and from the Central train station. There was some construction going on that created pedestrian traffic jams. So many tourists walking down the street, shopping and eating. For some reason, the frite stands were the most popular. We were eager to get away from the crowds.

top_reviews.title: Red carpet into the city centre
top_reviews.review: As the main avenue that connects the Amsterdam Central Station to Dam Square, Damrak is effectively the red carpet laid out to usher visitors arriving on trains into the city centre. Originally the mouth of the Amstel River that has been partially filled in the 19th century, today it is one of the main tram routes in the city and is also probably the city's busiest thoroughfare in terms of pedestrian traffic. Lined with vibrant restaurants, shops and hotels, this bustling street is undoubtedly a gaudy tourist trap, but nevertheless it's also the one street that visitors to the city could never avoid. Damrak showcases the 2 extreme sides of the city. On the northern-end closer to the central train station, you will come across probably the most picturesque view that you ever find in the city, ie. that of the canal water mirroring the gabled houses backing it. As you walk south towards Dam Square, especially towards the later part of the day, you will also find garbage accumulated on the sidewalks - a definite eyesore and disrepute to the city.

name: Dutch National Opera & Ballet
description: Dutch National Opera & Ballet creates, produces and presents both traditional and innovative opera and ballet productions of the highest quality. As one of the largest cultural organisations in the Netherlands, Dutch National Opera & Ballet brings all aspects of the ballet and opera world’s artistry, technique and craftsmanship together in its own specialised workshops and rehearsal rooms.

name: Het Scheepvaartmuseum| The National Maritime Museum
description: The National Maritime Museum holds one of the world's largest and most notable maritime collections including paintings, ship models, navigation instruments and sea charts. Discover 500 years of Dutch maritime history and its strong link to society of today and tomorrow.
breadcrumbs: Het Scheepvaartmuseum| The National Maritime Museum
address: Kattenburgerplein 1 Community Marineterrein, 1018 KK Amsterdam The Netherlands

top_reviews.title: Lovely covered courtyard
top_reviews.review: Must confess we were pretty museum’d out by the time we visited but still enjoyed it. Entry included with our I Amsterdam card so we went. If you walk there, as you cross the bridge heading towards museum from centraal station direction, look across to the right and you can see the only windmill in Amsterdam city in the distance. The building is fabulous, make sure you go down to the bathrooms as the vaulted area down there is impressive. We didn’t look at everything. We took the audio guide on offer but found we read the info boards rather than listening to the guide. The replica sailing ship is well presented, quite tricky to move around if you’re not too mobile and as you’d expect, mind your head! Favourite museum displays were those related to navigation in a starlit section and the section on books/maps. Fascinating to see these early “travel guides” with their depictions of local scenes and people’s. Do sit in the courtyard area which is a lovely space, wait until there’s a burst of sunshine and see the effect of the roof line shadows across the walls because it’s beautiful.

top_reviews.title: Great history and current exhibits
top_reviews.review: Beautiful building. Exhibits are very interesting for adults. Varied exhibits about the city as a port, its growth, past and current use, and the broader Dutch maritime history. We learned a lot. Special exhibit on whaling was great for kids to understand that history. The audio guides are free with tickets and were helpful to understand more. Cafe had some good food and wasn’t too expensive. They have a kids menu.

top_reviews.title: A good insight into the VOC and all things nautical
top_reviews.review: A very large building with a stunning courtyard, very relaxed feel. Lots to see in various galleries but not overhwhelming, nicely curated exhibitions on various different aspects such as navigation history, where our food comes from, old maps, and the VOC as you'd expect. The day we arrived the large reconstructed ship was away, the steward at the desk very kindly told us BEFORE we bought our tickets, so we had the choice to return a day later and see it - really glad we did as it was quite stunning and gave you an inkling into what it might have been like as a sailor back in the day. Rather complicated lockers were the only downside!

top_reviews.title: Decent Nautical Museum
top_reviews.review: The Maritime museum is located around a mile away from Amsterdam Centraal station on foot. Alternatively you can take bus 22 from Centraal to Kattenburgerplein which is a short walk from the museum. It is housed in a fine building with a courtyard in a dock area. Due to time constraints I had only an hour to look around but there was plenty of interesting content. I enjoyed the Rescuers at Sea exhibition which featured many interesting stories of volunteers working for KNRM (Dutch Lifeboat Service). There are many good nautical paintings on display covering the golden age when the Netherlands was a major seafaring force. The Food for Thought exhibition was informative and dealt with food production and waste. The Netherlands is the second largest exporter of agricultural produce (USA is the first). Unfortunately the old ships normally anchored in the dock were away for restoration so couldn’t be viewed. Overall, an enjoyable experience at a cost of €18.50.

top_reviews.title: Maritime history you don’t know!
top_reviews.review: Beautiful 14th, 15th and 16th century paintings of ships and battles. The map room was especially interesting. It was surprising to see that Dutch sailors trading with China and Japan in the 14th century. Take a tour of the replica of a ship; that’s probably the most interesting thing for kids. The courtyard has tables and chairs where you can rest and a restaurant to buy food and drinks.

top_reviews.title: A really huge museum
top_reviews.review: I must admit this museum was much larger than I expected. Some sections were easy to anticipate, but others really astonished me. Probably the most attractive ones are about whales and waling, as well as the ship East Indiaman Amsterdam. There were three more ships to visit for an additional payment, but I skipped that and yet was exhausted after exploring all exhibitions. Plan to have more than 3 hours for a visit. A disclaimer: I was there in August, 2023, not September.

name: Westerkerk
description: This magnificent Renaissance church (circa 1620) is identified by its high tower (more than 245 feet high,) and is the site of Rembrandt's grave who was buried here in 1669.

name: Museum Van Loon
description: In the heart of Amsterdam on the Keizersgracht the house of the Amsterdam regent family Van Loon can still be seen. Seven days a week the family opens their home and collection to the public. Get a glimpse of the life of the Amsterdam Van Loon family in one of the finest canal houses of the city. Due to corona measures, the museum is temporarily closed on Mondays and Tuesdays (but still open for private tours and rental opportunities).

name: Bridge of 15 Bridges
description: There is one bridge in Amsterdam’s central canal belt that gives a view of no less than 15 bridges. This unusual sight is found at the bridge crossing of the Reguliersgracht with the Herengracht, on the side with odd numbers. Standing on this bridge with your back to the Thorbeckeplein, you will see six arched bridges in a row. To the left you will find six more over the Herengracht and on the right you will see the next two. The 15th is the bridge you are standing on. It is particularly worth coming here at night as the bridges are illuminated giving one of the most beautiful and romantic views in Amsterdam.

name: De Hallen Amsterdam
description: De Hallen, a cultural hub with a social heart located in Amsterdam-West since 2014 in a former tramdepot. National monument. A vibrant center for fashion, art, culture, hospitality and crafts. Eat & Drink In the FoodHallen you will find a collection of the most tasteful and varied cuisines. Right behind is the Kanarie Club, a spacious restaurant with a lovely terrace, and Remise47, the restaurant of Hotel de Hallen. Enjoy a delicious cup of coffee and a good book in the Belcampo reading café, the living room of the neighborhood. Art & Culture De Filmhallen with its 9 screens is a must-see for every film lover. Opposite you’ll find Beeldend Gesproken, a gallery for contemporary art. Right across is thr public library (OBA). Recycle is a bike shop/workshop training people in bike repair. At the Maker Market you will find cool local brands. Denim City connects denim experts and includes Jean School, partnering with top brands. Kinki Academy trains future hairdressers.
address: Hannie Dankbaarpassage 47, 1053 RT Amsterdam The Netherlands

top_reviews.title: Great for foodies !
top_reviews.review: Great mixed food hall with a brilliant variety of reasonably priced food types. Finding a table can be a challenge but once seated the experience is really good. Drinks were not overpriced either, would highly recommend.

top_reviews.title: Great burgers in the food hallen
top_reviews.review: We were staying at the hotel next door so visited a couple of times. The shops were expensive and quite niche and wouldn’t bring me here again. However we did love the food Hallen! The Butcher burgers were amazing. The wait was quite long but it was worth it. They were juicy and really tasty. I’d say it was the best burger I’ve had!

top_reviews.title: Good variety of food
top_reviews.review: Good place with lots of variety of food, hard to get a a table during busy periods but a good atmosphere. We went as a large group so was good as there was options for everyone. Food prices were a bit pricey but food was all tasty.

top_reviews.title: A Good Start
top_reviews.review: On several previous trips to Europe, we typically gravitate towards town markets and food halls. Our first visit here. Luv the variety of cuisine and the ease in picking our choices. We were a party of 4 about to start a 3-week holiday. Luv the place. We will be back!

top_reviews.title: Lots of Food Options!
top_reviews.review: Lots of great food options from all around the world and lots of seating available. Can get busy and feel slightly crowded but adds the experience. A tram station very close by and is easily accessible. The burger in the picture is from ‘the butcher’ stall and is prepared right in front of you.

top_reviews.title: Lovely atmosphere and spot for variety of lunch choices
top_reviews.review: We came across this in the rain and wanted somewhere to have a look inside. Really enjoyed the atmosphere. Very busy. Lots of choice for food from around the world. No gluten free though so I watched the family eating (story of my life anyway) and they then had some lovely looking desserts. Some shops too which had artistic vibes. Some lovely jewellery.

top_reviews.title: Nice
top_reviews.review: With its array of international food stalls and a couple of bars, it's a hub of excitement. Visiting on a bustling Saturday lunchtime meant it was packed, making finding a seat a bit of a challenge—but totally worth it! It's not your average fast-food center (but still fast-food); it's a lively spot bursting with flavor. It reminded me of a place I visited in Ghent not so long ago.

name: De Poezenboot
address: Singel 38 G, 1015 AB Amsterdam The Netherlands

name: HEMA
description: There are more than twelve Hema department stores around Amsterdam that offer everything from soup to nuts.

name: Rembrandtplein
description: One of Amsterdam's main squares, this is an ideal place to sit on one of the many terraces and watch the world go by.

name: Museum Quarter
address: Nicolaas Maesstraat 2D, 1071 RA Amsterdam The Netherlands

name: Johan Cruyff Arena
description: The largest stadium in the Netherlands and home to the Ajax football team, it has played host to legendary sporting matches and music concerts.
address: Johan Cruijff Boulevard 1, 1100 Amsterdam The Netherlands

top_reviews.title: Stadium Tour
top_reviews.review: Went on the stadium tour during the summer whilst in Amsterdam. Stadium is very easy to get to via public transport and train station is right outside the stadium. Tour guide was very knowledgeable with some great information about Ajax and the stadium. Answered any questions too. Only disappointment on the tour was not being able to see the pitch as it was covered up for a concert but I knew about this in advance. Club shop is also very good and because we booked tickets in advance they gave a discount on items bought in the shop.

top_reviews.title: VIP tour
top_reviews.review: VIP tour was nice. Tour guide spoke in English, answered questions, took photographs at different stages of the tour. Enjoyable experience even for non-football fans. Pleasant staff.

top_reviews.title: Quicker than expected
top_reviews.review: Smaller than expected so didn't take long...bar on site was nice! Staff very knowledgeable, we didn't book a guided tour but still made time to talk to us. 10% discount in shop with ticket doesn't mean much as so much on sale and discount not available with sale goods

top_reviews.title: Best tour guide in the Netherlands
top_reviews.review: Getting to the entrance to buy the tickets and start the tour was bit of an adventure but we found it. One tour guide on Friday 21st of June took it upon himself to add to what would have been a very basic experience and he made it memorable. Highly recommended.

top_reviews.title: Iconic Stadium
top_reviews.review: We always go to tour football stadiums whenever we visit another country and have been looking forward to this one for years. We were advised that we would not be able to go onto the pitch which we though was completely understandable but when we got to the pitch we realised that this was because there was some sort of game show being filmed. The rest of the tour was very quick but still an amazing stadium and I'm glad we've been to see it in person.

top_reviews.title: Tour
top_reviews.review: Was in Amsterdam for weekend and was hoping that. Ajax would be at home but they weren’t. So decided to book a tour stadium. You might be better off to get an Uber to the ground. The tour lasted almost 2 hours. You got to see everything. Dressing rooms, boxes sit in dug out, press room. The tour guide we had Archie was really good and knew his stuff a very good knowledge.

name: ARTIS Amsterdam Royal Zoo
description: Stroll among the shady trees, admire the diversity of plants and animals, travel to the stars, enjoy our heritage. Visit ARTIS Amsterdam Royal Zoo and experience nature right in the city centre.
address: Plantage Kerklaan 38-40, 1018 CZ Amsterdam The Netherlands

top_reviews.title: ARTIS ZOO AMSTERDAM VIST
top_reviews.review: This is the second time we have visited Artis Zoo , going 2 years in a row. Zoo is excellent, many different animals to see laid out in a spacious, well kept and easy to get round. Manged to see and get up close to animals such as, Black Panther, Giraffe, Red Panda, Chimpanzees Gorilla, Zebra and many many more. The indoor rain forest, Insectariium and Planiterium are all again excellent and very informative. Staff very friendly and helpful Weather was also great both times we went, which helped. Would 100% recommend if you are in Amsterdam!! The Clarks from Scotland .

top_reviews.title: Great couple hours
top_reviews.review: Reasonably price zoo with a variety of different species of animals. Well kept and managed to a high standard. But there’s also a lot of upgrading to certain enclosures so not as much to see as they would normally be

top_reviews.title: Brilliant Zoo
top_reviews.review: Brilliant zoo, loads of cool animals and attractions. Although it was December and cold, most of the animals could easily be seen. Butterfly house and the seals were easily our favourite's, could watch them for hours. Reasonably priced, would definitely return again.

top_reviews.title: A worthwhile visit to this small and lovely zoo.
top_reviews.review: A lovely small and gorgeous zoo. It was lightly raining but it was still fairly crowded. The animals seemed happy and had space to roam. It was small and well designed. We were happy to be staying where we could walk over and enjoy this special place on our last day. It's worth a visit!

top_reviews.title: Pleasant
top_reviews.review: The partner and I enjoyed our time here. Plenty of Animals to be seen who were very socialable. They were not afraid to make themselves seen or heard. The layout was surprisingly good. I felt like I managed to see everything without having to go back on myself or go in different directions. The staff on hand were helpful. They even kindly held our bags somewhere safe so we could explore. Elephants and Giraffes were a fun highlight.

top_reviews.title: Lovely city centre zoo.
top_reviews.review: I'm glad we visited this zoo. It's small but well laid out. On the day we visited it was raining rather heavily, so it wasn't too busy. There are lots of animals to see, and the ones we saw all looked well cared for and happy. Because of the weather there were some 'no shows' but who can blame them for not wanting to come outside in the rain! The aquarium is undergoing renovation atm, so that wasn't open. We took shelter in the small mammals walk through, which didn't disappoint. We had lunch too, which was reasonable and filling. All in all I would definitely recommend this zoo for a visit. Good value for money.

top_reviews.title: Decent Zoo
top_reviews.review: Going in the winter isn't brilliant. Also went not long after opening time which was probably a mistake. A lot of the animals still indoors and there's no access to the public for most of the enclosures. Spent a couple of hours there and was only able to see about 50% of the animals. But most importantly, they all looked well cared for and had a good amount of space to move around.

top_reviews.title: Go visit - you won’t be disappointed!
top_reviews.review: We spent a couple of hours walking round the zoo and it really was a delight. There are lots of animals, all in a fabulous setting. We enjoyed watching the gorilla’s, they were content in eating their way into their enrichment. It must have been some kind of sweet/savoury liquid, it was encased in a flat tube and they had to use a piece of stick to get to their reward. The jaguar gave us a right fright as we walked down a dark passageway to see it walking towards us! We couldn’t see the glass, but were very happy when we did! We would have stayed longer but it absolutely chucked it down. Definitely recommend. And what a great idea of the little pull along trucks for little ones to sit in whilst going round the zoo! Genius!

top_reviews.title: Well worth a visit
top_reviews.review: A great range of animals, some of which are not on display in many other zoos. Some areas looked a little neglected or not overly-friendly to the actual animals on display (time to make it more about the animals and less about the visitors). We went in winter and the selection of food available was somewhat disappointing (not all cafes were open).

top_reviews.title: A stimulating day out.
top_reviews.review: An excellent collection of animals, insects, etc. All housed in interesting and suitable conditions. Overall the collection was in well kept and historic parkland. Choice of eating facilities, enjoyed both lunch and a final cup of tea and cake. The zoo particularly appeared to cater for families, discovery activities, etc. A playground for children within the zoo offered relaxing fun.

name: Fabrique des Lumières
description: See art come to life in the largest immersive digital art centre in the Netherlands - Fabrique des Lumières - located in the former 19th century gas plant in Westergas area, Amsterdam. A large industrial space with walls up to 17 meters high hosts immersive exhibits by classical, modern and contemporary artists. The stunning artworks are brought to life with advanced technology, through 100+ state-of-the-art projectors and accompanying music. From the 10th of March 2023, step into a new world and experience an ode to two spanish masters! During this visual and musical spectacle, the most famous psychedelic works of Salvador Dalí will come to life to the rhythm of the music of the legendary band Pink Floyd. The works of Catalan architect Antoni Gaudí - a great inspiration for Dalí - completes the overall immersive experience.

top_reviews.title: Beautiful
top_reviews.review: We saw the incredible ‘Destination Cosmos’ exhibition on my birthday and it was wonderful. The visuals were paired really well with music and it was totally immersive. Spent about an hour in the room, moving to new locations and different seats.

top_reviews.title: Gaudi, Dali and Pink Floyd
top_reviews.review: We walked, just turned up and purchased tickets on the door. A superb audio and visual delight combining Gaudi, Dali and Pink Floyd. Sit , stroll and enjoy the experience at your own pace. Don't forget to visit the mirrored room and small gallery for a few extra treats.

top_reviews.title: Great experience with friends, better if you have prior knowledge about topic
top_reviews.review: The place was easy to find, you can walk or take the bus there. I had a really good time at the show, but I couldn't help but wish there was more info available. Even though I know quite a bit about space, it would've been nice to learn more about the different parts of the show. All in all good experience, and really fun to do with friends.

top_reviews.title: A WOW! experience.
top_reviews.review: We were looking for something to do during our last minute trip to Amsterdam and came across Fabrique des Lumières and we were so glad we did! It is truly an amazing experience if you are a fan of the magnificent art work of Van Gogh and Mondrian among others. The artwork is projected around the room and every wall showed a different element of each piece. It was a fully immersive and fantastic experience and we would highly recommend a visit.

top_reviews.title: A hypnotic display of art
top_reviews.review: We were bowled over by this attraction. The display of works of art was hypnotic, accompanied by great music which was mostly classical but with some jazz too. The pictures in the main room were animated and constantly moving but there was a Side room where you could see a continuous display showing the actual pictures. There are other rooms with different types of display, all worth seeing. Difficult to describe, but we loved it.

top_reviews.title: A new way to experience
top_reviews.review: What an intense and wonderful experience! Certainly nothing like any art exhibition we have visited before, the show (which it felt more like) was absolutely captivating. Would be interesting to see the landscape project in the larger room!

top_reviews.title: Magical
top_reviews.review: My visit to « Fabrique des lumières in Amsterdam » was truly magical and exceptional. I was amazed by the moving paintings and I left feeling inspired the creativity and innovation on display. It was a truly unforgettable experience that I would highly recommend to anyone interested in the world of Art.

top_reviews.title: Brilliant! A relaxing and mesmerising experience!
top_reviews.review: One of the best things we’ve done in Amsterdam! I thought we would spend about 30 mins in there, but ended up staying an hour and a half as the art is so mesmerising. It’s such a wonderful experience and a unique way to experience art. The accompanying music is also so relaxing! There are some love bars and restaurants surrounding it. We went towards the end of the day and it was quite quiet. Absolutely worth a visit!

top_reviews.title: Excellent Art Show for Couples
top_reviews.review: Wonderful, dynamic presentation in a beautiful and historic venue. The Dutch Masters show was excellent. We pre-purchased our tickets for a Friday evening, not too crowded and no lines. One of the highlights of our trip to Amsterdam.

top_reviews.title: Mesmerising art experience!
top_reviews.review: I enjoyed this way more than I thought I would. The immersive experience was amazing. I sat on the side and watched both shows that were offered back to back. The choice of music with each piece of art is spectacular! I really enjoyed this and would definitely go to another experience like this again. The only reason it is 4 stars is because the building is generally far from all other amenities. Our flight got delayed on the first day so we couldnt visit it, but they gladly swapped the tickets for us, great customer service!

name: Artis Micropia
address: Plantage Kerklaan 38-40 Artis, 1018 CZ Amsterdam The Netherlands

top_reviews.title: great museum
top_reviews.review: as a microbiology student, this place was amazing!! i could have spent all day here. absolutely attend one of the daily talks if you can, it was fascinating. there is a ton of information and unusual microbes, plus rate opportunities to look down microscopes at microbes such as unusual algae - something i particularly enjoyed! even if you aren't particularly interested in micro you will still enjoy an hour or more visiting here. :)

top_reviews.title: Interactive and interesting museum
top_reviews.review: Great museum! Very interesting content displayed in an interactive and visually pleasing way. You could see live microbes under microscopes that you could operate yourself. A fun afternoon out for adults and kids alike!

top_reviews.title: Very interesting museum!
top_reviews.review: We visited this on our first full day in Amsterdam. There are so many interesting exhibits to look at and the interactive exhibits really add to the experience (as well as being able to collect stamps as you go round!). We have recommended this to friends and family too!

top_reviews.title: A zoo for microbes!
top_reviews.review: Great attraction, suitable for adults, teens and young kids with interactive exhibits and tons of microbes to learn more about. You can scan your body, analyse a kiss, and study life under a microscope. Everyone working there was super friendly and happy to help too. A fun and unique experience.

name: Verzetsmuseum Amsterdam
description: Explore true stories and destinies of everyday people during World War II in the Netherlands. What did life look like? What choices did you have to make? Step back in time at the Resistance Museum.
address: Plantage Kerklaan 61, 1018 CX Amsterdam The Netherlands

top_reviews.title: absolutely worth a visit (with kids)
top_reviews.review: Went with three kids aged 8-9-9 (Dutch), in order to see the children's-section. Very well told, in four stories. Kids learned more about WOII, from different perspectives. Combined our visit to Amsterdam with Anne Frank House.

top_reviews.title: Resistance museum.
top_reviews.review: Although it was a bit difficult to locate we got a friendly greeting and very helpful staff. The museum.does have audio devices to help for those of us who couldn't speak Dutch to save our lives Easily used and the displays put a very "human face" to the occupation of the Netherlands. Learnt a lot of things and they didn't 'gloss' over the dark parts of this history. Anyone with a historical interest would be advised to add this to their Amsterdam itinery.

top_reviews.title: Terrific experience at Verzetsmuseum (WW II Dutch Resisistance Museum) in Amsterdam
top_reviews.review: We started our tour when the museum opened so it was less busy than later. The arrangement of the exhibits, the personal stories that lend color to the broader events and especially the very easy to use audio guide (point at number on wall and it plays the appropriate segment) made it an outstanding visit. Well done to the museum for such an outstanding experience.

top_reviews.title: Great Museum!
top_reviews.review: We visited this museum on a very rainy day and were so glad we did. We learned a great deal about the brave men and women who tried to fight against the Nazi repression in Amsterdam during WW2 and also about what it was like to live in the Netherlands during that very difficult time. Your museum admission includes an audio guide that works very well. But if you would prefer to read the descriptions, they exactly reflect the audio.

top_reviews.title: Powerful, well thought out exhibits
top_reviews.review: We found this a really powerful experience and the exhibits were very well curated. It focuses on the people involved in World War Two and the resistance. Fascinating, inspiring, and sad stories. The audio tour was helpful and there are plenty of panels with additional information. The exhibits were very well designed and different from each other. There is a special kids exhibit that our kids really liked and so did we as adults. We spent over two hours here.

top_reviews.title: Glad we added this to our trip
top_reviews.review: Very clean, well laid out museum. Extremely interesting. The audio boxes worked really well. We had watched A Small Light about Miep Gies and her role helping the Franks during the German invasion. The museum has many, many more stories of the Dutch resistance and how they helped other humans. Experiencing this place inspires reflection that is needed now.

top_reviews.title: Excellent, well designed museum
top_reviews.review: We are so glad that we devoted 90 minutes to this museum. It tells the story of Dutch resistance during the Nazi era, and does it with appropriate detail, nuance and personalization. Having walked by the Anne Frank House, we actually opted for this museum instead of the tour there. And are glad we did, feeling we got a more expansive view of that horrific period. The Resistance Museum is extremely well and logically designed and curated. Further, it avoids easy, black-and-white answers fitting the history of that period in which the Dutch were trapped with no good or obvious options.

top_reviews.title: Powerful, emotional and well constructed museum about Dutch resistance to the Nazis
top_reviews.review: This is an outstanding museum, telling the story of Dutch resistance to Nazi occupation. The personal stories, audio and visual resources and items on display are wonderful. I would definitely recommend this museum to any visitor to Amsterdam.

top_reviews.title: Brilliant, fantastic . I cannot praise it enough
top_reviews.review: We pencilled in up to two hours for this visit but we stayed for four hours . From the start to finish was amazing. You have an audio guide that was second to none. You can do it in the order you want and if you miss a bit you can go back and point your audio gadget at he piece you have missed and listen to it . Real people's stories from the time, photographs and short films. I went in with very little knowledge and came out with a wealth of knowledge and a thirst to learn even more. The best museum I have been in for a long time.

top_reviews.title: Underrated!
top_reviews.review: I started this day with a self-mapped walk of the Jewish quarter, then came here right when this museum opened at 10am. This was completely worth it. I'm a social justice activist myself, and I've been absolutely horrified at the the things happening in the world. I'm also a holocaust history nerd (enthusiast seems crass here), and I've always struggled to understand how something like this could happen in the Netherlands. This museum really helped me understand this history. I went through it very slowly, interacting with some of the exhibits as much as possible, listening to everything I could on the audioguide, and really trying to be present with the information. It's a lot, and it can certainly overwhelm you--I have a feeling a lot of people need to pick and choose what they engage with, and it's fine. I ended up spending about 2.5 hours here, and it was totally worth it. I'm so glad I went. I think this was the most underrated spot I went to in all of Amsterdam

name: Brouwersgracht
category: Bodies of Water Points of Interest & Landmarks

name: Magere Brug
description: Famous "flat" bridge over the Amstel River

name: Sexmuseum Amsterdam Venustempel
description: Explore how sex has evolved throughout history at this museum with its extensive collection of explicit paintings, pictures, recordings, and artifacts. The exhibits detail over 100 years’ worth of sensual love from all the cultures of the world. Some pieces will make you laugh, while others are more thought-provoking. The museum, which opened in 1985, is the oldest of its kind still in operation. It’s located at the Damrak waterfront, one of the most vibrant areas in downtown Amsterdam. When you’re done touring the exhibits, grab a beer or a snack, or enjoy a canal cruise. – Tripadvisor
category: Speciality Museums Art Museums History Museums

top_reviews.title: Very bizarre experience
top_reviews.review: We thought we’d come here while in Amsterdam to kill some time looking around. It was about €10 per person which isn’t extreme It was a very random experience looking at all photos and models through the years, spent probably around an hour or so here. It gets a little busy around midday when we arrived. Not wheelchair friendly as there are a lot of stairs to gain access to other floors If you’re in Amsterdam it’s something to do if you have time on your hands

top_reviews.title: Blonde haired women on entrance is rude af and is the reason why it doesnt get 5/5
top_reviews.review: For €10 its well priced. The toilets are something to be seen a quote from my friend "the most impeccable toilets iv seen in Amsterdam" lots of interesting photos. Very amusing. Alot of stairs and staff are rude and miserable. But worth a visit

top_reviews.title: Inexpensive Time Killer
top_reviews.review: We attended the museum to kill time between a meal and another planned trip. It was overall ok with some interesting exhibits and some really bad (old and unrealistic) mechanical displays. The overall impression was that sex and pornography has interested various world cultures throughout history. There was a separate exhibition for LGBTQ++ rights which was great to see and also interesting Entrance was 10 euros each which I felt fair.

top_reviews.title: Shady sex experience
top_reviews.review: Visited this as part of our Amsterdam trip in February. Obviously we all know the story with Amsterdam and its links to the sex industry, drugs and whatever craziness it presents so therefore this was a must visit for us. The museum itself has this sort of “shadiness” feeling about it as you enter, being met by some smartly dressed hosts. When you enter you’re immediately met by various statues, images and a couple of electronic animations of a man being relieved in a toilet and also another man who opens his coat and surprises you. I think the whole point of the museum is to introduce you to the world of sex, the history behind it etc yet i felt this was just full of pornographic images from the 1910s all the way through to current day and also a small exhibition on historic condoms and other contraception. For the entry of ten euros per person it isn’t the worst, but when it’s done i don’t think i would make it a priority to return.

top_reviews.title: A quick hour stop
top_reviews.review: We popped in here upon passing it on our way into Amsterdam and thought "Why not". It is what it says on the tin, we had a good laugh here and there was a lot to see, but just know it is not very accessible at all, with a lot of very narrow staircases. It killed an hour for 20 euros each so you can't complain too much, but it's definitely a see once-and-done kind of place.

top_reviews.title: Interesting visit.
top_reviews.review: I think this is one of those must see things in Amsterdam, it's quirky a bit of fun and not to be taken too seriously. It won't pass anymore than an hour or so and I suppose for that reason the €10 entrance is a little expensive. There's actually quite a bit to see though, and I supposed the amount of time you can spend there depends how much in detail you are reading the items watching videos evt. It is entertaining, I'd say it's worth a visit but I wouldn't go again. It can get busy at times.

top_reviews.title: Bit tacky.
top_reviews.review: What do you expect for a sex museum- hard to say! We felt it was a bit tacky to be honest and once you have seen one 1950’s porn picture you’ve seen 100’s! Wouldn’t feel the need to go back. Was a bit underwhelming. The giant phalus’s upstairs make for a fun group photo.

top_reviews.title: Fun!
top_reviews.review: 8/10 We had a really good experience here. €10 to get in which was great! Can get around the place really quickly to take your time Really funny! Also really interesting if you take a minutes to actually read the art ect!

top_reviews.title: Something to do
top_reviews.review: We were at the Sexmuseum Amsterdam in June. This was not a highlight of things to do while in Amsterdam but we were in this area so we said why not. The museums exhibits are dated and could be working better but again, we were in this area and, the Sexmuseum was something to do. It took a little over a hour to go through. The layout of the museum isn’t the greatest if there are many people walking around looking at the same exhibits you are trying to view but again, this was just something to do considering Amsterdam is know for the “Red Light District”.

top_reviews.title: Sexmuseum Amsterdam Venustempel - 27/06/2024
top_reviews.review: Sexmuseum Amsterdam Venustempel - 27/06/2024 An interesting experience... It is a fairly central part of the city (At least to me, I walked past it a few times). One of those places I walked into for the fun of it. A good laugh with people.

name: Ziggo Dome
address: De Passage 100, 1101 AX Amsterdam The Netherlands

name: Tour de Bonton
description: Discover the best-kept secret of Amsterdam and have an exclusive tour behind the scenes of the most famous high-end strip and sex club in Amsterdam. During this approx. one-hour tour, which is hosted by a former sex worker, you’ll discover a beautiful, exclusive brothel in a discreet canal house next to the Heineken Experience. During this unique Amsterdam brothel tour a friendly and experienced former sex worker will be present. You can ask her anything you want to know. Listen to the funny, strange, and interesting stories that only real insiders in the industry can tell. You'll hear what it's like to be a sex worker in Amsterdam, learn about safety measures, local prices and what it is like at night in a club like BonTon. You’ll also get the opportunity to discover all the rooms including the dressing room and VIP rooms by yourself and you can climb the stripper poles at the bar. Enjoy one of Amsterdam's unique tours and you'll certainly have a story to tell when you get back home!

name: EYE Film Institute Netherlands
description: EYE Filmmuseum is the Dutch centre for film culture and heritage. On april 5 2012 EYE opened the doors of a futuristic building on the banks of the river IJ right next to Amsterdam's Central station. A free ferry service runs right at the back of the train station and takes you across in less than 3 minutes (24/7).The EYE building was designed by Delugan & Meissl Associated architects from Austria and is freely accessible. It holds 4 screening rooms that showcase a wide variety of films, from historical classics to the latest arthouse premieres. There is a 1200m2 exhibtion space with 4 changing exhibtions every year.There is a large terrace with a spectaculair view over Amsterdam.
