The bar and restaurant are open 7 days a week from 10.00pm to 01.00am.

name: Amsterdam Tulip Museum
description: The Story of the Tulip. The museum features exhibits and films devoted to the tulip, the unofficial national flower of The Netherlands. From Sultans of the Ottoman Empire, Dutch Merchants of the Golden Age, to gardeners today, the tulip has captivated people around the world for centuries. This fascinating flower has inspired artists and brought great wealth and even economic ruin to people who have fallen under its spell. Explore the tulip's history and discover the remarkable journey the flower bulb has taken from the wilds of the Himalayan highlands to a garden like yours. Conveniently located in the Jordaan district of historic Amsterdam near the Anne Frank House.

top_reviews.title: A little gem
top_reviews.review: A friend suggested we visited. As it was included with the I Amsterdam card we thought we’d pop in as we were walking up Prinzgracht canal. Paid entry is I think €5. We spent about 25 min in there as it’s small, but it was lovely and came out feeling we’d learnt something. Nice shop too. Added advantage, unlike so many Amsterdam museums you don’t need to pre-book, you just walk in.

top_reviews.title: Interesting diversion
top_reviews.review: This small museum gives a good history of something synonymous with the Netherlands. We didn't know what to expect when we arrived, and were pleasantly surprised. Having no idea about tulips beforehand, it was interesting to learn about how they became so linked with the Netherlands. Over only five rooms, the museum is able to impart a lot of information.

top_reviews.title: Overall interesting
top_reviews.review: Nice visit with interesting information, well presented. I wouldn't have paid for entry if not included in iamsterdam city card though. The shop upstairs was very very busy but the staff were friendly and doing their best to serve people quickly.

top_reviews.title: Great with the city card.
top_reviews.review: The museum isnt that big but it's still very interesting and worth an hour of your time. Would recommend getting the city card if you're planning to go as the general entry price seems a bit steep for the size. Lovely gift shop with lots of great choices.

top_reviews.title: Small but Delightful and Informative!
top_reviews.review: We had not planned to stop here, but we are so glad we did. The Tulip Museum is a small museum located behind a bulb shop near the Anne Frank House. In a surprisingly small space, the museum takes a whimsical journey through the history of tulips from their native lands to Turkey to the Dutch bulb trade to modern industrial bulb harvesting. The videos are brief and informative and the displays are good. Definitely worth the modest entry fee.

top_reviews.title: A great value for 5 euros
top_reviews.review: I stopped here to use up some time before my Anne Frank tour, which is just a one minute walk up the street. I’m glad I did. It was very well presented with a mix of photos, film, and artifacts in English that let you understand the lifecycle of tulips, how they came to Holland, and why they are still important. 30 minutes is ample time for a visit, but they have a small but excellent gift shop, too.

top_reviews.title: Tulip Museum
top_reviews.review: This is a cute little museum to learn about the history of tulips in Amsterdam and the farming process. It feels a little cheaply done and there isn’t a ton of great artifacts. It’s a short visit and there is a cute shop. We didn’t book in advance and were able to go in but it is extremely small so I imagine there is a small limit of people allowed in.

top_reviews.title: A real highlight
top_reviews.review: This museum was a highlight of our trip! Such a surprise and such a good price, especially as some of us are students. There was so much information about tulips and so much more interesting than we could have imagined! We came away with tulipmania!!! The shop is also lovely and the staff were very helpful, looking forward to planting our bulbs.

top_reviews.title: Small museum, but provides a good history of the Netherlands tulip industry.
top_reviews.review: You enter through the gift shop and frankly you could go in there and not even notice the museum entrance in the back of the store. It was cheap to enter ($5 or so) and that is about what it is worth. It is a small 3 room affair that you do at your own pace, but you would have a hard time spending more than 40 minutes looking at the exhibits. You can tell a lot of heart went into the museum and it was informative and easy to understand. More for adults, wouldn't be very fun for kids.

name: Amstelpark
address: Arent Janszoon Ernststraat 1, 1083 GP Amsterdam The Netherlands

name: De Bijenkorf
description: De Bijenkorf meaning beehive, is the most renowned chain of premium department stores in the Netherlands. With flagship stores in Amsterdam, The Hague, Rotterdam and Utrecht and smaller stores in Amstelveen, Eindhoven and Maastricht, it’s the favourite shopping destination for Dutch and international visitors. Wander around the store to find the perfect gift for your loved ones, or take a break from shopping to enjoy a fresh cup of coffee at our cafees or restaurants. As a premium shopping destination, de Bijenkorf provides excellent services such as tax free shopping and offers an unrivalled assortment of brands in fashion, cosmetics, shoes, accessories, toys, homeware and much more. Luxury brands include established international designers ranging from Louis Vuitton, Cartier, Hermes and Saint Laurent, to Tommy Hilfiger, Calvin Klein and Hugo Boss.

top_reviews.title: De Bijenkorf Christmas Display
top_reviews.review: I am not much of a shopper but the Christmas Display of De Bijenkorf department store in Amsterdam somehow catches my attention each and every year. This year, the Christmas Display of De Bijenkorf did not disappoint me. If you happen to be in Amsterdam, it might be worth a couple of minutes of your time to look at them🌷🌷🌷 (Correction: i am mixing up the months again. For my Hotel Penaga review here below, the date of experience should be October 2023 and not September 2023. Again, my sincere apologies for my error😃)

top_reviews.title: Disappointing
top_reviews.review: Although a lovely department store, the cafeteria was extremely disappointing. We wanted a healthy salad and asked several employees in the food court to point us to the right food station, but nobody seemed to have any idea of what was on offer and didn't seem to care. We finally found the large salad station but it was completely empty and featured only a tureen of soup. Why? So we ended up with cheese and salad sandwiches, which were extremely dry (possibly a Dutch thing) so needed butter. The charge was 1.5 euros for two small pats.

top_reviews.title: Excellent staff and a wonderful shopping experience
top_reviews.review: Sir or Madam, your shop and staff are excellent. I have tried to find out if you still sell the square Royal Delft Rabbit money boxes. When friends have babies I always get one in your store besides other shopping. Do you still stock them. Regards George Armstrong. commodoregeorge@hotmail.com

name: Museum Of Prostitution Red Light Secrets
description: Step into an intriguing world that remains hidden to many and discover the secrets of the Amsterdam Red Light District in in the world's only Museum of Prostitution. Take a look behind the scenes of the oldest profession in the world and experience what it feels like to take a seat behind one of the famous windows. Visit Red Light Secrets and experience how surprising and exciting a museum can be!
breadcrumbs: Museum Of Prostitution Red Light Secrets

top_reviews.title: You simply must visit
top_reviews.review: Such an interesting eye opening thought provoking experience. A real opportunity to look at life from the other side of the glass. Excellent museum, shocked, amused, entertained, educated and informed all in one visit.

top_reviews.title: Definitely worth the visit if your interested in more than just what's behind the red lighted windows
top_reviews.review: Walking around the red light district left us with a lot of questions about the history behind the red light district and those who work there. Here we found some answers. Taking a break from wandering and getting a little behind the scenes info made our stay much more worthwhile then just walking around gawking lime the masses.

top_reviews.title: Complete change of perspective!
top_reviews.review: We visited this attraction at night and found it incredibly interesting, educating and thought provoking. It really helped understand the culture of the city and the people behind the faces in the window. The audio guides were very good and staff were extremely helpful. It was very busy but this did not take away from the experience. Some complained at having to queue outside despite having pre-booked tickets, but this didn’t take long and we didn’t mind at all. Definitely add to your must visit list!

name: Joods Historisch Museum
description: Explore Jewish life in the Netherlands in these four superbly preserved monumental synagogues. From contemporary art to modern history: paintings, ceremonial objects, films and 3D presentations provide a full, up-to-date survey of Jewish religion and culture in the Netherlands over the centuries. The Jewish Museum features the Jewish Museum junior where children of all ages are encouraged to connect with Jewish culture.
address: Nieuwe Amstelstraat 1, 1011 PL Amsterdam The Netherlands

top_reviews.title: Beautiful and Huge
top_reviews.review: I originally had planned to spend part of the day working remotely from the library on my last day in Amsterdam before taking the Nightjet train to München. As luck would have it, my Airbnb hosts graciously let me stay late into the afternoon on my final day so I did not need to use the library, but I did stop by the library for a bit to have lunch and check out how practical it would be to work from there. They had an overwhelming number of places where you could work, with outlets and good lighting. I did quickly try to get on to the internet, but struggled a bit and did not take the time to get it figured out. I'm sure the staff could have helped if I had asked. The cafe at the top had nice food and a beautiful view from the terrace.

top_reviews.title: Impressive Library a short walk from Centraal Station
top_reviews.review: I met some friends here in June. Right away the security guard was welcoming and cordial. He recommended the cafe/restaurant with a view over the city and river on an upper floor. It's a beautiful library. I noticed it offers many events and services for locals and newcomers to the city. Fantastic section for children!

top_reviews.title: Superb place to enjoy a breathtaking view and a toilet break (and it’s free!)
top_reviews.review: Here's a secret tip while you're in Amsterdam........ Where’s the best free place to take a toilet break and enjoy the view of Amsterdam? Yes, it's none other than the OBA Oosterdok, the Central Branch of the Openbare Bibliotheek Amsterdam (Amsterdam Public Library). Opened in 2007, the OBA Oosterdok is actually the 2nd largest library in Europe by floor space, behind the Library of Birmingham in the UK. Located in the eastern docklands within a short walking distance from the Amsterdam Central Station, this public library boasts 10 floors, more than 1,000 seats, 1.5 million of catalogues items, a 300-seats theatre, and opening hours of 90 hours per week (which is double the average opening hours of the conventional libraries in Europe). Best of all, on the top floor (7th floor) is a cafe-restaurant with a terrace that offers spectacular panoramic views over the city. There's no better place to spend a couple of hours especially when it rains in Amsterdam. The best things in life are indeed free!

name: The Amstel
category: Bodies of Water Points of Interest & Landmarks

name: The Upside Down Amsterdam
description: Everyone, young and old, will find their inspiration when they step out of their current reality, into a new fantasy world that we call The Upside Down Amsterdam. With our mind bending world we want to inspire you to create, to do things you’ve never dreamt about and to have fun. You can interact with our rooms and decors, you can touch everything and you can go all out.

name: Rijksmuseum
description: The Rijksmuseum is the museum of the Netherlands. The completely renovated Rijksmuseum tells the story of the Netherlands from the Middle Ages to the 20th century. Including works by Rembrandt, Vermeer, Frans Hals, and more! Most famous is Rembrandt's masterpiece the Night Watch. A new display of the collection, a renewed building, new public facilities, a revamped garden and a new Asian Pavilion. Open daily from 9 am to 5 pm.

top_reviews.title: Take a Guided Tour
top_reviews.review: Remarkable art museum with exhibits you will not see anywhere else in the world. We chose a guided tour. Our small group was lead by a very experienced guide who understood the works art we saw, but the artist who was responsible for each of them and the history associated with each piece. There is no way visiting on our own could replicate the experience had. Costs a little more but an excellent value.

top_reviews.title: Overwhelming
top_reviews.review: There is so much in this museum it is quite overwhelming - if you have the i Amsterdam card I would suggest going twice (you can get time slots easily online). The Vermeer and Rembrandt paintings were the highlights for us but there are many other amazing paintings, and other objects of interest such as a huge model ship, ancient musical instruments and some incredibly detailed dolls’ houses. The modern section of the museum isn’t very memorable compared to the rest.

top_reviews.title: Go Early!
top_reviews.review: Glad we went for a 10am booking as when we came out the entry queue was really long. We made straight for level 2, The Night-watch and Vermeer. This way there were only a handful of other visitors around. Later on when we walked past there was significantly more people and harder to get close, As you’d expect the cafe is extremely expensive and you’re better walking into the Museum Plein for a coffee before or after your visit. Easy to get exhausted by the number of works in there so do pick up their free highlights leaflet and use that.

top_reviews.title: Fabulous collection of Old Dutch Masters
top_reviews.review: THE Museum to go to, especially if you have only a limited amount of time. The collection is fabulous and Rembrandt's Night Watch is the star of the show. We spent over 5 hours here, and had a snack in their cafe which is great. Terrific apple pie just enough to keep you going. You will not want to miss this museum.

top_reviews.title: Heaven for art lovers
top_reviews.review: We heard it was recently renovated. The museum is great, it's very big and there are alot to see and absorb and you need to spare enough time to be able to enjoy it. you may need guide. We usually go on our own, so it wasn't a problem. Don't miss the night watch gallery!

top_reviews.title: Nice. Could take a day!
top_reviews.review: The building is beautiful, and has a great cafe/restaurant attached - highly recommend going! You could easily spend an entire day looking at everything in this museum! Definitely worth visiting, but I'd do it on a day where you don't have anything else booked. Maybe a good idea to visit the cafe for a mid-way break!

top_reviews.title: Well worth a visit, book in advance and take your time
top_reviews.review: A lovely museum, a great range of different exhibits with something to interest everyone. We loved the building, found it to be very spacious and this added to our visit. There was no sense of rush here and we had plenty of time to look at the things which caught our eye. Some of the paintings that really caught our eye included Vermeer's "The Milkmaid" the quality of light is incredible. There is one of Willem Heda's still life studies which is remarkable considering it was painted in 1635 and of course there is the Night Watch by Rembrandt which is absolutely massive. As a point of note, we visited in October 2023 and the Night Watch is currently being studied to try and identify the best way to preserve the canvas. In brief they are monitoring vibrations and this involves a number of devices including a glass cage/box device to help. This does mean you don't have the full picture to see, but it is well managed by the museum and is perfectly understandable. Another good thing the museum does, is that it has information cards for key exhibits which you can read when standing with those items. These cards are approx A4 in size, double sided and can be found in boxes near the exhibit. You can simply chose the language of your choice, pick them up and spend time reading about the subject before replacing them, great idea. The main tips we would give are: 1. Book in advance, saves time and means you will definitely get in at the time and date of your choice. 2. Don't rush when you're inside, there is a lot to see and plenty of room, so pace yourself. 3. There is a Van Gogh self portrait here, it is lovely but don't base your visit because of this, go to the Van Gogh Museum next door if you want to see his work.

top_reviews.title: Great Museum
top_reviews.review: Excellent museum with wonderful works very well displayed ad explained. I would encourage the audio tour as it helped guide you through the sections f the museum. The museum’s information provided a great deal of historical knowledge I was heretofore unaware of.

top_reviews.title: Learned about Dutch art and history
top_reviews.review: Gorgeous art, sculpture and collections. We spent most of our time in the main galleries to see the Van Gogh, Rembrandt, Vermeer, and others. However we did venture into the smaller galleries and learned a lot about other artists. You can download the audio guide to your phone and listen to save the 5€ for the audio guide there. They have a QR code that you can use to get the guide. Our kids only lasted two hours but easily could have spent four there. It was the local school break time and they had special kids activities on when we visited.

top_reviews.title: Amazing Art Inches Away
top_reviews.review: There are so many amazing pieces of art —whether it’s paintings, silver, glass, ceramics etc. Make sure that you visit the gallery showing the most famous pieces of art. We went in October and even then, it was crowded. The headsets are not useful. Don’t spend the extra money. FYI there are a lot of stairs. Elevators are available but for general attendees, you will be climbing the stairs a lot.

name: Vondelpark
description: At one of Amsterdam's most famous parks, travelers can enjoy a host of outdoor activities amid beautiful English-style landscaping. Here, you can hike the countless trails or ride a bike around to spot charming bandstands and even a sculpture by Picasso along the way. Have a picnic by the pond as herons and ducks waltz past or pop by one of the many cafes in the park. You might want to visit between April and May to see the park awash with tulips in bloom or between May and September to watch live concerts at the open-air theater. – Tripadvisor

top_reviews.title: Nice park that is quite massive
top_reviews.review: We had rented bicycles from A-Bike Rental that is close by, as there are no bicycle rent shops inside the park. The park is quite massive, though there are lots of people cycling, walking or just relaxing. Little to do inside the park though, so we just cycled several times around.

top_reviews.title: Lovely City Center Green Space!
top_reviews.review: Unplanned circumstances allowed us to become well acquainted with Vondelpark in the heart of Amsterdam. We had Sunday reservations at both the Van Gogh & Rijksmuseum. We had no idea that the Amsterdam Marathon was being run that day! Sunday morning, as we tried to access the Van Gogh Museum, we discovered that we would have to use an alternate, longer route. We hurried through Vondelpark and finally found a bridge that took you over the participants. After our time in the museum, we leisurely walked through the park to then discover that getting into the Rijksmuseum would be just as difficult. Vondelpark is a beautiful green space in the center of Amsterdam!

top_reviews.title: European floral paradise!
top_reviews.review: Spring is coming! Visiting Vondelpark during the spring season is a wonderful experience. This iconic park is blooming with snow drops and other spring flowers right now. We had a lovely stroll in the sun and enjoyed a take away coffee from one of the carts in the park. My 2 year old played with the ducks near the pond. When you walk here you know: life in Amsterdam is good. So don’t hesitate to visit this park if you want a peaceful getaway right next to the hustle and bustle of the city center.

top_reviews.title: Pretty park
top_reviews.review: Vondelpark is ideal for a walk, cycle or run. We hired bikes for an hour (25 euro for 2) from Macs, about half mile away. This meant cycling on cycle lane to the park. There doesn’t seem to be anywhere within the park to hire bikes. We were looking forward to seeing lots of tulips in the park, being April, but there were hardly any, apart from in baskets in the lake, but otherwise, a lovely park.

top_reviews.title: Outdoor Greenery
top_reviews.review: Spectacular park with limestone paths throughout. You can relax near one of the water features or stroll through the trees. The weekends can be very busy with so many runners and bikers. It's a great place to enjoy some outdoor greenery.

top_reviews.title: Lovely park
top_reviews.review: Beautiful park not far from Rijksmuseum. During warm days a nice place to relax either in the sun or in the shade, during the evenings a lovely pretty quiet place for a walk, run or biking where you can hear the birds sing even in the middle of a city. There are a few place where you can buy something to drink but I didn't try them.

top_reviews.title: Well worth a couple hours to enjoy the sunshine!
top_reviews.review: Really beautiful park, easily accessible via the trams. Had been scared to rent bikes and ride them around the streets of Amsterdam, but rented a few for a cycle around the park. It was amazing! If you do cycle around the park, make sure to follow the rules of the road (cycle on the right, indicate with hands before turning). The Picasso statue blends right into the park, such an interesting way to show that art is for the every day. Unfortunately we weren’t able to see any storks, however the island they are supposedly on still looked beautiful! We went mid day and it was busy, but not too crowded. Overall, a delightful park to visit.

top_reviews.title: It's a Beautiful Park - But It is Just a Park
top_reviews.review: I went to Vondelpark twice. Once I went on my own and I also took a bike tour of the city where we biked through the park. It is a beautiful park to walk or bike through. There is not much to see except for the beauty of the park. There are lots of runner, walkers, cyclists, etc... in the park and the park is very well maintained. If I was to run while on my trip I would have definitely headed over to the park. If you are a photographer there are lots of beautiful views. If you want to just experience Vondelpark and say you were there, 30-60 minutes is more than enough. I would compare it to Central Park in NYC. There are people that can walk the 6 mile road in Central Park for 2-3 hours and love it or you take several hours to see the whole park and all of the areas, or you can say an hour in the park is enough to experience it and say you were there. It would also be similar to Lumpini Park in Bangkok.

top_reviews.title: 'It's slightly out of the centre but can be accessed from many different entrances.'
top_reviews.review: I like to call it the Central Park of Amsterdam because there's so many things to see, from sculptures, water features and ponds. It's slightly out of the centre but can be accessed from many different entrances. The park itself is huge and there's many green open spaces so perfect for having picnics and catching up with friends. When we visited the weather was stunning, 25 degrees celsius to be exact, so it was very busy but there was still plenty of room to sit down and soak up the sunshine. Overall, a stunning park which is well kept and litter free. Would highly recommend if the weather is good and you're looking to relax whilst visting Amsterdam.

top_reviews.title: Nice park but watch out for all the bicycles
top_reviews.review: Did a walk through and indeed it is a beautiful park. On the other hand it is a regular bicycle thoroughfare and any peace you might feel has to be tempered by the constant vigilance for bicycles. Easy to pick a path but difficult to cross the main bike path.

name: Stedelijk Museum Amsterdam
description: The Stedelijk Museum is an international institution in Amsterdam dedicated to modern and contemporary art and design. The Museum aims to provide a home for art, artists and a broad range of publics, where artistic production is actively fostered, presented, protected, reconsidered and renewed

top_reviews.title: Ok…not great
top_reviews.review: We wanted to see some modern art as well as traditional art, but didn’t find much of this memorable. You can’t even take a small canvas bag in, so you can’t sit and sketch if you want to. The cafe was table service only and was incredibly slow just for coffee and cake at a quiet time in the afternoon. This museum is ok but I wouldn’t say it’s a high priority if you have limited time in Amsterdam.

top_reviews.title: Good alternative
top_reviews.review: If you can’t get in to the Rijksmuseum or Van Gogh Museum because you didn’t get tickets in advance, this is a very good alternative. Wonderful range of modern art, presented in periods such as 1950s to 1980s and post-1980s. And no need to book!

top_reviews.title: Nice!!!
top_reviews.review: Every now and then i drop by this museum. I loved the Chagalls hanging here. It is almost never as crowded as the two nearby world-famous museums so i quite enjoy the space and especially the quietness here. The museum shop is quite lovely too✌✌✌

top_reviews.title: Stellar collection of modern art
top_reviews.review: Stedelijk Museum of Modern Art was included in my I Amsterdam card and one of the highlights of my trip. Absolutely wonderful collection! Chagall’s “Maternity” and “Bella in Green” stole my heart, as expected. There are several interesting portraits by Russian avant-Garde painters of the early 20th century: Kokoshka, Matyushin, etc. All of these paintings are in the first room. After that, the collection takes more “modern” turn. For the fans of Yayoi Kusama's installations, there is her famous erotic “Boat” in different shades of blue. I didn’t spend much time on the ultra-contemporary art and on Mondrian as well. Two hours of joy for an art lover like me… and no crowds at all.

top_reviews.title: All the names you expect but a little soulless
top_reviews.review: I tried first to visit the Stedelijk on a Friday evening, when it's late night opening, but the queue was so long and not moving much that I gave up. I didn't have an advanced ticket but speaking to people in the queue this didn't make any difference as there were not separate queues for tickets and ticketless. Fortunately I was able to re-arrange to go first thing on a Tuesday morning when it was much quieter. The lovely lady who manages the entrance hall (more of whom shortly) said it is always extremely busy from Friday through the weekend, so if you can visit on a weekday do so. Once inside it was clear this is a big building, and it took me a good 3 hours to see the whole thing, and that was without visiting the Marina Abramovic exhibition that was on (I'm not a fan). I went around in room number order so as not to miss anything, which meant I came to a Matthew Wong exhibition first. I quite like his work but I found the amount of it here a little overwhelming and to be honest was pleased to come to the end of it and move on to the permanent exhibition. Like all modern/contemporary galleries there are likely to be a things that leave you cold and things you love, but they'll be different for different people. Suffice to say the collection is so extensive that there'll be something for everyone. Note that the lockers here are before you pass the ticket gates, so make sure you have everything you need with you. The lockers are the key code type, and if you find you can't open your locker when you return (and you're dashing to catch a train) don't dissolve into a gibbering wreck like me, just ask the cloakroom attendants who will call the lovely lady running the place who will use her master code to sort you out and send you on your way in two minutes. Overall my view of the Stedelijk is that it has all the names you expect, gives a comprehensive view of 20th Century art, but is a little soulless and lacking in an identity.

top_reviews.title: Well worth visiting
top_reviews.review: The Stedelijk has a great collection of Modernist Art from the early 20th century up to today. The original building has been extended with what locals refer to as the "bathtub" and the collection has grown since our previous visit several years go. Pre booking is not absolutely essential but remains a good idea as it is busy. The staff are very helpful and the displays are wheelchair friendly.

name: Museum Het Rembrandthuis
description: Rembrandt lived and worked from 1639 to 1658 in this 17th-century house, which today is a museum that pays tribute to the artist's life and career.

top_reviews.title: Interesting and Informative Self-Tour!
top_reviews.review: And of course you can't visit Amsterdam without Rembrandt! He was a true Amsterdamer, and although he never left the Netherlands, he felt that he traveled the world through art! The Rembrandthuis Museum is housed in a residence that was his home for about 20 years. He was an affluent & respected artist, but after a time, financial difficulties forced him to find a smaller home. The audio guide allowed you to tour the residence at your own pace. Not only was the property the families personal residence, but it also was his studio, a studio for art apprenticeships, and his art dealership. The house, in true 17th century splendor, is adorned with the prints, sculptures, and paintings of other painters from Rembrandt’s time. A collection of almost all Rembrandt’s etchings, prints, and the graphic techniques he used are also shown. No visit to Amsterdam would be complete without a visit to the Rembrandthuis Museum.

top_reviews.title: Rembrandt’s house
top_reviews.review: From extremely hectic Rokin I took a nice walk to the Rembrandt House Museum, which was included in my I Amsterdam card. The museum has the largest collection of etchings created by the artist. His drawings are on different subjects: nature, love, family life (the drawing of his “Prodigal Son “ is there)… The rooms are recreated to produce an image of the house he had owned with his first wife Saskia, and then with Hendrickje Stoffels, whom he never married, and his son, Titus. There is a replica of his work room, his bedroom and his kitchen, the place where he was mixing paints and preparing canvases… I also looked at etching process demo, which was quite entertaining. You can also see the complete collection of Rembrandt’s etchings on the second floor. All of this was very interesting and brought me closer to one of my favorite painters, but to see his immortal art you have to go to the Rijksmuseum.

top_reviews.title: Don’t miss the Rembrandt House Museum in Amsterdam!
top_reviews.review: I purchased admission tickets online to see the Rembrandt House Museum in Amsterdam via Booking.com for my husband, teen, and me. Three tickets cost me approx. US$38.00 (€35). We arrived early in the morning of April 10th 2024, took a nap, and found our way there for our 3 pm timed entry. There’s lockers to hold your backpack & other belongings. The free audio tour is a must do. Full of info about Rembrandt’s work, his Influences, his personal life, and the house where he lived from 1639 to 1658. It was surreal to stand in the studio space in the house where he worked, to see his etchings, and to learn about how he prepared his paints. The museum shop also carries very reasonably priced items to bring home as souvenirs. Don’t miss it. Well worth seeing and learning about Rembrandt. The space is beautiful.

top_reviews.title: Amazing place
top_reviews.review: We visited the Rembrandt House which represents the place where Rembrandt was living and working. We can see it all of the reasons that he was going bankrupt. Before selling all his worldly goods he wrote a complete setup which ended in a thick book. So we know exactly what has been inside in this house and it could be reseted once again.

Most of the things and works were not actually in the house and were added later on, so that part isn’t actually authentic. Still very nice, especially his and his pupils’ works. The house itself though is fantastic, you feel teleported in time.

top_reviews.title: Highly recommended!
top_reviews.review: Very well-organized, clean, and engaging. The staff was very polite, also. Do not lose the opportunity to imagine Rembrandt's life in his working and living space. Highly recommended! (Just a suggestion to the Museum: providing the possibility to choose the playback speed on the guided tour would be the golden touch.)

name: Wereldmuseum Amsterdam
description: Wereldmuseum Amsterdam is een museum over mensen, gevestigd in het indrukwekkende rijksmonument aan het Oosterpark in Amsterdam. Een omvangrijke vaste tentoonstelling en regelmatig wisselende exposities tonen objecten, die stuk voor stuk een menselijk verhaal vertellen. Verhalen over universele menselijke thema’s zoals rouwen, vieren, versieren, bidden of vechten. Van Afrika tot West- en Zuidoost-Azië, van Nieuw-Guinea tot Latijns-Amerika. In Wereldmuseum Amsterdam ontdek je dat we ondanks de verschillen, allemaal hetzelfde zijn. Wereldmuseum Junior is het kindermuseum, speciaal voor kinderen van 6 t/m 13 jaar. Als je Wereldmuseum Junior binnenkomt, stap je in een andere wereld. Het is een ware beleving waarbij alle zintuigen worden geprikkeld. Je leert door te doen. In de huidige doe-tentoonstelling ZieZo Marokko ga je op reis met Esmaa, Fatima, Nasrdin en Yousef en ontdek je het land van hun ouders. Wereldmuseum Junior biedt kinderen een open blik op de wereld.

top_reviews.title: Beautiful interior
top_reviews.review: I like to come here sometimes. The inside of this quite huge building is really quite beautiful. There are always exhibitions here with different themes. Worth taking a look if you are in Amsterdam and have some time over after your sightseeing ✌✌✌

top_reviews.title: Eclectic museum
top_reviews.review: Eclectic museum with exhibits on their colonial.history, plastics, Arabian music artists among others. Very much a learning and understanding museum - makes you think. Bear in mind now called Wereldmuseum as has brought multiple museums together. Cafe is self service.

top_reviews.title: Finally we are talking about it
top_reviews.review: I visited the Wereldmuseum on a school trip the other week … obtained terrible museum fatigue in the process but the exhibit we saw was very informative of the masked history of the Netherlands. This has been a certain point of frustration for me during my time in Amsterdam. The complete lack of discussion of colonization and imperialism imbedded within Dutch history is seldom talked about. I appreciated the Wereldmuseum for this.

name: Museum Het Schip
description: Museum The Ship is located in the imaginative social housing complex ofthe same name designed by architect Michel de Klerk. This expressionistic housing block was built in 1919 for social housing corporation Eigen Haard. The triangular shape of the building inspired its nickname “The Ship”. It is one of the best examples of the “Amsterdam School”– a movement in architecture and decorative arts that spread across all of the Netherlands.
category: Speciality Museums Architectural Buildings History Museums

top_reviews.title: Quintessential Dutch market
top_reviews.review: We landed early in the AM; by the time we cleared customs and dropped off our bags, the market was open. I was surprised to find that there wasn't any coffee for sale (and the cafes around it were packed), but there were stands selling Poffertjes (small dutch pancakes), fresh produce, and aged cheese that was safe to travel with because they don't need to be constantly refrigerated. The focus on this market was really thrift, and you can find a lot of great things here if that's your interest.

top_reviews.title: Compared to I like to unwind at the end with a nice glass of red wine at Cafe Daalder, for instance!
top_reviews.review: I enjoy taking my time exploring and finding new things. I purchase fruit, cheese, outerwear, shoes, blouses, t-shirts, and a lot more. After that, I go to The Church to see my preferred book sellers. I always succeed when I buy books on my career and pastime.

top_reviews.title: We went there since a buddy told us to.
top_reviews.review: We adored the sights and scents of the abundant produce, cheeses, meats, and seafood. Together with stalls offering both new and old clothes, there were sellers selling antiques. There were several kiosks filled with gorgeous sweaters and coats because winter is almost approaching.

name: NEMO Science Museum
description: Expand your world at NEMO Science Museum. In the largest science museum of the Netherlands you will find proof that science and technology can be captivating for all ages. The remarkable building on top of the IJ-tunnel offers lots of exciting hands-on activities. At NEMO you can experience the joy of science and technology, by blowing gigantic soap bubbles, watch an enormous chain reaction and experiment in a real laboratory. In a variety of exhibitions you can 'Take a journey through the mind' or learn that there is more than meets the eye when it comes to sustainable electricity and smart transportation at 'Smart Technology'. The creative mind behind NEMO, built in 1997, is Italian architect Renzo Piano. He had a clear vision for his design of the NEMO building, with its very own piazza 22 metres above water level.

top_reviews.title: Very nice
top_reviews.review: We really like the visit here, all the workshops labs and installations are very well done and organised. Also the upper floor is very interesting and also the threated themes are very impoortant and inclusive. Absolutely it s is worth a visit!!

top_reviews.title: Fun interactive exhibits for all ages
top_reviews.review: Our kids loved this museum and so did we as adults. It’s not particularly Dutch in that you can find good science museums all over but it was a wonderful way to break up other Dutch/Amsterdam museums that we visited with the kids. We spent three hours here with our two kids. There are loads of interactive exhibits. The restaurant is convenient as you have to go back across a large street into the neighbourhood to get to restaurants. It’s not inexpensive but the food was good.

top_reviews.title: AMAZING
top_reviews.review: I went on a class trip there was about 30 of us all teenagers and we had the best time. This place isn’t limited to children or teenagers though because the adults there lived it too. If you are going make sure you bring a good camera because there are great photo opportunities. Try everything because It’s all worth it and make sure you take a lot of time out of your day for it as we were there for hours on end. Honestly one of the best places.

top_reviews.title: Great science museum
top_reviews.review: Fantastic Science Museum. Loads for the kids but great for us adults too who like to experiment. Highlight was seeing the chain reaction. Didn't do the lab. As half term was very busy so didn't do as much as we hoped but will go back during term time.

top_reviews.title: Incredible experience!
top_reviews.review: My second time visiting Amsterdam and so a second visit to the NEMO science museum was a must. Lots of interactive stations and learning areas on all sorts of things science!! We don't have children but still really loved our experience. Staff friendly and helpful. Lockers available for coats.

top_reviews.title: Expensive day out but ok rainy day activity
top_reviews.review: Decidedly average especially for €17+ euro per person. We watched the “chain reaction” display twice as that was probably the most engaging thing but most of the explanation was in Dutch so it was hard for non Dutch speaking children to get properly involved. Lots of very disruptive children queue jumping, not taking turns, at times quite stressful. Our 8 year old enjoyed it but the 11 year old (normally very science-oriented) found it boring. The science lab was worth queuing for but by the time we found it we had ran out of time. Lunch (4 portions of vegetarian chilli) was over €50, all drinks extra, no tap water available. Children complained that their school chilli was better (!) and couldn’t bring themselves to finish even though they were hungry. Ok for a rainy day but hard to justify the cost when compared to the free science museum or natural history museum in London.

top_reviews.title: Fun Day in Nemo Science Museum
top_reviews.review: Nemo science museum is easily accessible by metro or boat. You will not miss it by its symbolic ship-shaped building and it is also opposite to maritime museum. My 5-year-old daughter loved the whole visit experience. The museum demonstrates science in different interactions, and live sessions which kids can easily engage with. The museum has all facilities such coffee shop, restaurant as well. The rooftop restaurant is definitely a good place to relax and have a bird view of the city.

top_reviews.title: Interesting, Intriguing, Innovative
top_reviews.review: Extremely Expansive, wise variety of interesting exhibits. Much better than the same old repetitive amusement parks. It has several floors and each floor has different sections. The Experiment Room on one of the Floors where you actually do a Project is just fantastic. Don't skip it. Then of course, the illusions pics that you take. The place takes a lot of time, engaging your interest, hence keep enough time. At the Top there is a nice Eatery with a beautiful outside area and most amazing views of the city. Dont Miss !

top_reviews.title: We had sun and it was hot but that was great because it was hot on the terrace. On the terrace is water and wind things. Childre
top_reviews.review: Very fun museums. I recommend that you skip first few floors and go to humania floor, beacouse it is gonna take you most of the time. Then cocertate to other floors. It depands how old your children are. The 2 floor is fin too. On every full hour there will be chain reaction on 1st floor

top_reviews.title: Very interactive
top_reviews.review: The place was hugely interactive. It was fun to get to have a go at the different activities and learn at the same time! I would say that it gets really busy especially near the interactive sections so come early and go to what you want to see first. We did get to see a show which was nice although I would say some people didn’t know how to be polite and were actively encouraging their children to start playing on the activity you are already on until you have to give up and move. The gift shop is alright but it’s expensive for what it is and doesn’t really have anything suitable for those above the age of 12

name: The Milkmaid Project
description: This is the 'BEST ART EXPERIENCE OF AMSTERDAM'! Step back in time and immerse yourself in the vibrant world of the 17th Century. Wander through our meticulously recreated museum, where every scent, texture, and detail captures the essence of life during this era. Discover the secrets of Dutch masters like Vermeer and Rembrandt, and uncover the stories behind their timeless paintings. Why just learn about history when you can become part of it? Pose as iconic figures like the self portraits of Rembrandt, like William of Orange, The Milkmaid of the Girl with the Pearl in beautiful reconstructed settings. The possibilities for you and you beloved ones are endless. This unique experience only takes one hour and you will leave our Milkmaid Project with a beautiful print in your hands. Ready to transform into a Dutch masterpiece? Book now and step into history.
address: Nieuwe Leliestraat 14-H, 1015 SP Amsterdam The Netherlands

top_reviews.title: Enjoyable afternoon
top_reviews.review: Sander provided us with an enjoyable afternoon and a quality keepsake from Amsterdam. He provided an interesting introduction to the artwork and built up the excitement. The attention to detail when taking the picture was great and they were edited and delivered really quickly.

top_reviews.title: A truly unforgettable cultural experience. Get ready to jump in the past!
top_reviews.review: Sandro's remarkable talent and scholarly insight truly elevate the experience at his studio. His meticulous recreation of 1700s paintings transports visitors to a bygone era, revealing his extraordinary craftsmanship and deep understanding of art history. The passion he exudes for Vermeer's work is infectious, infusing each piece with an authentic essence that captivates the soul. Guests are not only treated to an artistic spectacle but also an educational journey into the mind of a true master. Sandro's studio is an oasis for art enthusiasts, offering a profound and enriching immersion in the world of classical art.

top_reviews.title: Very special must-do!
top_reviews.review: Sander has a great story to tell about the Milkmaid by Vermeer and has a brilliant studio in 17th century-style. The clothes, the props, everything breathes this amazing period in time. With great patience and joy in his work, he is able to shoot the right picture of anyone or any group. A must-do, when you are visiting Amsterdam.

top_reviews.title: The Milkmaid Project
top_reviews.review: The Milkmaid Project is the vision of professional photographer Sander Veeneman. Over the past three years, he has researched the works of Vermeer and Rembrandt, among others, to create a studio in which to capture in photography what was painted by the old masters. I arrived out of the rainy streets a few minutes early for my appointment and was kindly offered a cappochino. There followed an engaging conversation of his analysis of Vermeer’s The Milkmaid to recreate in studio a setting faithful to the times and materials painted by the masters. We reviewed various settings and selected the tableau of Portrait of A Scholar of 1631. While Sander set to work staging the photo, including a 17th century leather bound book he purchased at auction, I followed his instructions in donning the costume. Lights, camera, and an engaging photo session of about 20 captured images. Hard to keep a straight face with some of Sander’s light humor but he knows the works the your image is based on. Following his prompts, we found a very nice rendering and a nice photo of an afternoon well spent. I have no hesitation recommending your participation, whether you seek a serious image or a more light hearted version.

top_reviews.title: A Journey Through Art with Sander's Lens
top_reviews.review: Sander is an exceptional artist and historian, and our time with him was truly remarkable. When I surprised my dad with a family portrait session, Sander welcomed us into his world – his studio, an absolute wonder for any art enthusiast. I highly recommend booking a photography session with him. You'll not only leave with a unique souvenir but also with a sense of enrichment that will last a lifetime

top_reviews.title: A full immersion into Vermeer's work
top_reviews.review: Not only is it an incredibly fun activity, but it also sheds new light on Vermeer's work and the technique he used. Sander's passion for this project can be felt in every detail, starting with the welcome greating and the back story of how he discovered his passion for Rembrandt and Vermeer. The level of detail put into recreating Vermeer's milkmaid kitchen is incredible. Not only during but also after your visit you'll have a smile on your face thinking back about the shoot. Its almost as if you're going back to the 17th century to experience what life was like. The end result is even better than you expect it to be! If you're in Amsterdam and are looking to do something unique, then this is what you need to do!

top_reviews.title: Great experience, great fun
top_reviews.review: My kids took me to The Milkmaid Project for a photoshoot to celebrate my 75th birthday early december. It was a perfect happening. Alexander/Sander is a great guy, very professional photographer, much fun to be with, great storyteller. My photo choice was Rembrandt's 'The Scholar'. The result is a fine, beautiful portrait, now the eyecatcher on the wall in my livingroom...If you're around in Amsterdam and have some spare hours, go visit The Milkmaid Project ! You won't regret it !! Aart

top_reviews.title: Familyportrait.
top_reviews.review: Receive a gift voucher. With this voucher we wanted to take a different kind of family portrait than standard. That certainly worked. We received a very friendly welcome, were treated to a bit of art history and then dressed up for the photo shoot. This one was hilarious, but with a beautiful result. Even our 17 year old son had an enjoyable afternoon. Thanks Sander!

top_reviews.title: Unique family portrait
top_reviews.review: This was an amazing experience and the family portrait that was the result we will cherish for a long time. I initially thought that this was expensive but given their time, energy and enthusiasm and the uniqueness of what they offer, I don't think it's bad value at all. My advice is to just book it, you won't regret it!

top_reviews.title: History comes alive, with you as the leading character!
top_reviews.review: We just had an unforgettable experience thanks to Sander. This passionate photographer, skilled storyteller and humble historian has made our Amsterdam visit so special and memorable. Entering his domain is like stepping back into time, his camera the only 21st century prop. The costumes, the setting and his eye for detail enable anyone to turn into a Rembrandt or Vermeer model. We thoroughly enjoyed the session and adore the result. Thank you so much Sander!

top_reviews.title: Great Beer!
top_reviews.review: Unfortunately we came during their Oktoberfest celebration so the places was packed and only three beers were available to try. But the next day we visited their Voldenpark location and the the staff and beers were on point. Love trying craft beer in other countries!

top_reviews.title: Great place for a beer
top_reviews.review: Was in Amsterdam for a football match between Netherlands and Scotland, and having visited Amsterdam before, was wanting to get away from the central side of the city, and see what more it can offer. Had just been for a meal near by, and the "windmill brewery" had really taken my fancy, as I could see from across the road that for a Thursday night it was packed! Went in for a couple of beers, and was really good and a excellent alternative to the regular beers that the Netherlands has to offer.

top_reviews.title: Good Place.
top_reviews.review: I checked this place on a nice sunny afternoon. Some different selection of beers, followed by some other finger food options, nice terrace with a very good vibe made the full package. The only reason I didn't rank it higher was because of the staff. At least the person who took all my different orders was really single word answering and with no sympathy at all. In a place where you usually have to ask several different questions about beer and stuff, didn't really make me want further explore the options.

top_reviews.title: A beer beside the only windmill in the city - what’s not to like!
top_reviews.review: The only windmill in the city makes it a destination beer to say the least. Easy access by public transport as well as walking from the centre. The beer paddle was a great way to experience the beer (I had the classic one) and then you have plenty more to choose from if you want to settle in. A great range of beer snacks (we had the bitterballen with mustard). We went on a weekday so didn’t do the brewery tour - but that’s ok. Not much there if you don’t like beer though

top_reviews.title: Refresh and recharge
top_reviews.review: After spending time walking the street markets of De Pijp or Dapperstraad or going through the Maritime Museum, take an afternoon break here. Plenty of shade and breeze along with a couple of pints of craft beer restores the soul. Flights are available if you want to explore more flavors as you recharge.

top_reviews.title: Great beer and friendly vibes
top_reviews.review: Visited this place on a recent trip to Amsterdam and had a great afternoon. Easy tram ride from the centre of Amsterdam. It was a really hot day and was packed and a great atmosphere. My husband and I shared two of the beer flights plus some tasty bitterballen. Got chatting to friendly Dutch people sat around us. All in all a great afternoon. Bought myself a beer glass in a nice box for just 5 Euros to take home, which was a lovely souvenir. Highly recommended.

top_reviews.title: The best beer and biterballen we had
top_reviews.review: We have been there twice and the first time we have opted out for beer samples tasting. The second time when we went there, we didn't know what was the name of the beer we had tasted the first time. When we tried to describe it, the bartender figured out what we would like to drink, and gave us to taste a sample before ordering. I recommend this place to everyone who wants to relax and enjoy the atmosphere while having a good beer and a tasty snack.

name: The Cat Cabinet
description: A museum for cat lovers that features a collection of objects d'art wholly centered around the theme of our feline friends.

top_reviews.title: Cute but overpriced
top_reviews.review: Definitely one for cat lovers! This museum is full of cat paintings, statues and many other forms of cat memorabilia. There are also a few live feline friends running around who are absolutely adorable. The staff are friendly and polite. Unfortunately the experience is overpriced at €10 per person. We were in and out within about 25 minutes. Compared with some of the other museums, this doesn't represent great value for money. All bags are removed from you at the door and there are no lockers, they are simply looked after by the staff.

top_reviews.title: Cute Cat Museum with 2 kitties
top_reviews.review: Cute little museum with a bunch of cat memorabilia and paintings throughout the years. The back garden isn't open in the winter which was the only bad thing for us! This place has two kitties sleeping around, very good ☺️

top_reviews.title: If You Love Cats, This is For You
top_reviews.review: Quirky, off-beat, run by cat lovers. If you love cats, you'll love this place. If you don't, you'll feel you have wasted your 10 euros entrance fee. If it's for you, this is a good place to spend an hour. Located in an old mansion house, on several floors and with a back garden (open in early March), Katten Kabinet is a labour of love for all things cat. Lots of pictures, many featured cat themed advertisements going back to the late nineteenth century. Cat themed furniture, cat themed antiques, cat themed ornaments, cat themed items to buy (many being posters or cards of the advertisements), you get the gist. It's also home to a couple of cats; if you're lucky you may see one (totally ignoring all things human, it's nothing personal). Well, we liked it.

top_reviews.title: the place for cat lovers
top_reviews.review: Interesting museum and a must see for any cat lovers. However there were only a couple rooms open so there wasn’t much to see and we unfortunately didn’t see the cats :( Other than that we had a lovely visit. Staff were very friendly and helpful

top_reviews.title: Must-see for any cat lover
top_reviews.review: I visited on a Thursday morning. It started off quiet but the traffic picked up. There were two cats in residence that were delightful! On view for visitors included artwork, sculptures, and all sorts of knick knacks. There was a garden but it was closed off due to renovations.

top_reviews.title: Disappointing
top_reviews.review: I was disappointed, it was quite expensive for what it was…. Only took 20 mins to go through…but as we only went to kill some time it served a purpose. There isn’t much to read to tell you about the art and the artist. It is also very small! I didn’t even see any of the real cats people mentioned! I love cats but this was a bit boring! I wanted to learn something! Some cool cat pieces though!

top_reviews.title: A lovely museum
top_reviews.review: Very nice museum with a lovely array of cat things to look at, there are live cats in there although we didn’t see them :( there is also a garden but that was closed during our visit (April) it opens during nicer weather. It is quite small so you can get around it fast but we paid €5 and felt it was certainly well worth the price They don’t allow bags to be taken round but they let you leave it behind reception and give you a little cat card with a number on so you don’t take another persons bag. Loved it in here, the building was also very lovely, will have to visit again in the warmer months for the garden, and hopefully see the resident cats :)
